title: [CI] Testing node versions up to 10.22.
body: Included all interim versions.

title: Fix transform for ordinal→quantitative scales.
body:
Previously, invalid transform attributes were being set for an
ordinal→quantitative scale transition, because entering ticks were
undefined in the old (ordinal) scale, and exiting ticks were undefined
in the new (quantitative) scale.

Fixes #1620.

title: Add children(), ancestor() and parent() methods to d3.selection
Filter function did not get parent group index
body:
When filtering a selection/transition, the callback function was not getting the second group index. I am unable to build/test since npmjs is currently down, but it seems pretty apparent this is the fix.

Note that looking for other instances of this with e.g. `grep '\bi)' -R src/selection src/transition` it appears the transition tween functions are also missing this (and more difficultly so, since it looks like their third parameter is already used for something else) and perhaps the data bind (although AFAICT this third parameter may not be appropriate in that context anyway).

title: Set context of callback to data, up one level
modify stack layout to work with series of unequal lengths
body: - put in defensive check to allow unequal series lengths for stack layout

title: Use [] instead of charAt
body:
Replace `charAt` calls with `[]`.
Index lookup is ~10% faster and saves a few bytes.

title: Prefer selectstart to user-select.
body: Rather than both setting the user-select to none and suppressing the selectstart event, we now prefer to suppress the selectstart event if supported. This avoids redundantly setting the user-select style, which can be slow. Fixes #1599.

title: Allow min/max to be used as high order functions
body: Right now d3.min and d3.min require a little extra work if you have nested arrays. This PR requires that the second argument to these functions be a function, before it is called as an accessor.  This allows you to do things like `twoLevelArray.map(d3.min)` or `d3.min(twoLevelArray,d3.max)`.

title: Minor optimisation for projection.precision(0).
body:
When resampling is turned off, d3_geo_resample can return a special
transform that only performs projection of points to 2D, rather than
performing any additional computations such as conversion to 3D
coordinates for resampling.

title: Rename d3_svg_line{X,Y} to d3_geom_point{X,Y}.
body:
Also, add a number of missing imports: mainly "math/abs".

Fixes #1581.

title: Remove the children array for childless nodes.
body:
If data is updated so that some nodes no longer have children, and a
custom children accessor is used, then the children array was not being
removed for such nodes, which meant that hierarchical layouts were
incorrectly taking into account these children.

Fixes #1579.

title: Defer first tick to end of timer frame.
body: Rather than interleave the initialization of transition tweens with their first tick, defer the first tick to the end of the current timer frame such that any DOM modifications that happen during the first tick do not trigger a forced relayout when another tween is initialized (e.g., getComputedStyle).

title: Fix linear scale tick format precision for non-fixed-point formats
body: Function d3.scale.linear.tickFormat() computes the precision for formatting tick values, but assumed that the format was "f" (fixed point).  For other formats such as "s" and "e" ticks might have the wrong precision (e.g., not be uniquely labeled) because the "precision" value used in those format specifiers has a different meaning. This fixes that issue, and includes some unit tests which pass only with the fix.
- [x] reverse the order of polygons returned by d3.geom.voronoi

title: Use the owner document to create new elements.
body: Fixes #1533 and avoids “wrong document” error when appending elements to a different document than the one in which D3 was initialized.

title: Added an optional child accessor for hierarchial layouts #1570
Use `\0` instead of `\x00`
body:
Diff: https://github.com/mbostock/d3/pull/1569/files?w=1

In this case, `\0` can safely be used instead of `\x00`, since there are no digits immediately following it.

The UglifyJS output for `d3.js` is fine in either case. 

It seems the change in c6f9932035449a7efe942b55aa57a0eccf6b4fe7 was done by accident or because of a misunderstanding.

Ref. https://github.com/mbostock/d3/commit/c6f9932035449a7efe942b55aa57a0eccf6b4fe7

title: Tangent space projection
body:
This is a first stab at basic tangent space projection. For now it does not support general rotations of the sphere (just shifts in longitude).
- resolves #1554

title: Less confusing intialization of node positions.
body: Fixes #1561.

title: Preserve polygon exterior/interior ring ordering.
body:
According to GeoJSON, the first ring in a polygon should be the exterior, and subsequent rings should be holes that are inside the exterior ring.  This fix ensures that the rejoining of clipped segments preserves these semantics, by generating multiple polygons if necessary rather than generating all rings within a single polygon as it did previously.

Fixes #1558.

title: Optimized array push() used in many files
body: X-Ref 1bec3a67b

title: Strict mode: function inside if
body:
Uncaught SyntaxError: In strict mode code, functions can only be
declared at top level or immediately within another function.

title: Fix clipping bug for complex polygons.
body:
Intersection points are sorted along the clipping region edge relative to a particular point.  In the case of antimeridian clipping, this point is the South pole.  Previously, the first intersection was assumed to be an entering intersection, but this is not always the case.

The fix is to see whether the clip region start point (the point relative to which sorting occurs) is inside or outside the polygon being drawn.  If it is inside, then the first intersection point must be outside, and so forth.

The same applies to d3.geo.clipExtent.  Provision was already made for this, but this has now been optimised to use a single point instead of picking one of the four corners.

Another optimisation was to reuse this clip region start point to determine whether to interpolate all the way around the clip region edge.  Previously, this was done by testing an arbitrary point in the clip region.

The above fix seemed to have broken one of the tests, and this has been fixed by modifying the point-in-polygon routine slightly to handle points that might lie exactly on the polygon edge.

Finally, I noticed a regression with the recent clipExtent fix, where a polygon incorrectly being marked as “clean” (no intersections) on a per-ring instead of per-polygon basis.

title: Perform winding order check on unrotated polygons.
body:
We remove the rotation step that occurred prior to clipping, so that clipping processes unrotated polygons.  Note that clip regions are defined relative to the rotated globe, so clipping now needs a rotation parameter.

Rather than moving the rotation step so it occurs after clipping, the rotation occurs as part of clipping, using the rotation parameter to rotate streamed points.  Alternatively, points could be clipped against a rotated clip region, and then subsequently rotated as a separate step, but this seems slightly less efficient.

Fixes #1453.

title: Fix clipExtent bug.
body:
If a polygon does not intersect with the extent, but has one or more rings inside the extent, then the extent should be checked to see whether it is inside the polygon: if so, an additional exterior ring is generated.

Previously, this check was only made if there were no visible rings at all.

Fixes an issue noticed in #1453.

title: Zoom behavior: Enable/disable mouse-wheel zoom at runtime
body:
I was looking for an easy way to add the ability to only zoom when a meta-key was pressed, and it looked like this patch was one of the easiest ways to achieve it.  I am using it in my app right now, and it works perfectly.

Hope that it can help someone else.

title: New Voronoi implementation based on gorhill/Javascript-Voronoi.
body:
Twice as fast as the old implementation, easier to understand, and handles coincident or collinear points.

Still left to-do:
- [x] restore voronoi.links.
- [x] restore voronoi.triangles.
- [x] restore d3.geom.delaunay.
- [ ] handle coincident points (subsequent points currently have null cells).
- [x] get tests working again.
- [x] eliminate duplicate Liang–Barsky line clipping with geo/clip-extent.js.

title: The JS comment suggested by makc is added in the snippet.
body: The JS comment suggested by makc is added in the snippet.

title: Fix crash in ticks for empty d3.time.scale domain.
body: Fixes #1525. This was only an issue because the domain is extended by one millisecond when it is empty (for an inclusive upper bound).

title: Use the scale as the tick key function.
body:
Previously we were using string coercion as the key function for axis ticks. However, when the stringified value of the tick does not fully capture the representation (such as a date with millisecond precision, whose string form only has second precision; fixes #1529), string coercion is insufficient.

Fortunately, there is an equivalently-simple key function for tick identity: the scale! If the scale does not return a unique position for the given tick, then the tick would be overlapping, so it serves perfectly as the key function.

title: Fix point-in-polygon for multiple polar rings.
body:
Instead of detecting if any single polygon ring winds around a pole, we
consider the cumulative winding of all polygon rings together.  This is
consistent with the area calculation, which considers the cumulative
area total of all rings.

This fixes #1521: an issue with the Hammer Retroazimuthal projection,
which uses such a polygon with two rings, covering most of the globe.

In addition, drop the special handling of points at the south pole,
which might have been there to pass an incorrect test: a CCW triangle
touching the south pole, which was probably incorrectly thought to be
clockwise.  This fixes an issue with a “stripe” polygon rotated so that
a point is at the south pole, mentioned in #1453.

title: d3.index
Added `padding` to `d3.layout.pie`
body:
This is very handy instead of using `stroke-width`, which diminishes the visual value of small arcs in a pie/donut chart, and might intersect with other shapes in the chart. The spacing that each arc gets does not count against its value.

Example:

``` javascript
pie = d3.layout.pie()
        .spacing(2 * Math.PI * 0.01); //Each arc gets a spacer of 1% of the circle's size after it
```

![Example](http://i.imgur.com/jiUk48t.png)

title: Truncate non-integers for integer format.
body:
Instead of ignoring any non-integer floats, we truncate so that small
floating point precision errors don’t affect integer formatting.  This
is consistent with Python’s "%d" format.

title: Round step value in d3_scale_linearTickRange to fixed precision to prevent rounding issues on Windows Phone devices
body:
The following issue occured on a HTC Windows Phone 8S running the latest version of Windows Phone 8. 

When using the function Math.pow, the resulting values are slightly off the correct values for specific input parameters. That means while Math.pow(10,0), Math.pow(10,2) or Math.pow(10,3) correctly return 1, 0.01 and 0.001, Math.pow(10,1) results in 0.09999999999999 instead of 0.1. You can test this behaviour here (with an appropriate device): http://jsbin.com/IbEvAKO/1

I could only reproduce this issue on the HTC Windows Phone 8S but other Windows Phone devices or smartphones in general might be vulnerable to this issue.

The difference between the correct and the returned value might seem minor, but it somehow breaks parts of d3 which use the ticks of linear scales, e.g. axis. If axis lie within a range where the Math.pow value is off, the axis ticks will not be displayed at all.

My proposed fix just converts the step value to a fixed size string and then back to Number. Because the step value is always an exponentiation with a base of 10, no precision is lost during the conversion.

title: Remove dead code.
body:
This line doesn’t appear to do anything useful, since the parent node is
now saved in the closure.  Previously, this line checked to see if
target.parentNode was null, since this would cause a crash when
computing the relative position.

title: Fix d3.mouse touch fallback for HTML targets.
If present, use changedTouches[0] for d3.mouse.
body: Normally d3.mouse(this) is equivalent to d3.touches(this)[0] because the clientX and clientY properties of the event and the first touch are the same. However, on touchend the touches list is empty, and the clientX and clientY are 0! So instead it seems safer to use the position of the first changed touch for the default location of a touch event.

title: fix voronoi degenerate check (alternate)
body: After thinking about it a little bit, this seems like a better base case.  Though I still don't really know what's happening here.

title: fix voronoi degenerate polygon check
body:
To be honest I'm not exactly sure what's going on here, but this does seem like a valid guard for the code below, and it sure seemed to clear up my problem.

Let me know if I can add anything else or if this isn't a valid fix.

title: Fix spurious touchmove without touchstart.
body: Fixes #1497. Because we listen to touchmove and touchend events on the window, whereas touchstart events are restricted to the targeted element, it was possible to receive a touchmove event for a new touch that started outside the targeted element without first receiving its touchstart event. The fix is to put the temporary touchstart listener during the gesture on the window, like the touchmove and touchend events. We also use a capturing listener and temporarily disable the touchstart listener on the target to prevent duplicate touchstart events from being received.

title: Support simultaneous zooming on multiple targets.
body:
Fixes #1497, where a zoom gesture would break if a touch was started
outside the target during a gesture.

Each zoom gesture now only considers touches that were started on its
associated target element.  This allows multiple zoom gestures to occur
at once without conflicts.

title: Support parsing timezone offsets.
body:
Note that the resulting Date object can only be in the local timezone
(or UTC), due to the limitations of JavaScript Dates.

Fixes #1494.

title: Remove component.json to avoid bower warnings
body:
Bower gives the advice to switch from component.json to bower.json.
When installing the package through "bower install" or "bower update" bower outputs warnings if the repository config hasn't been migrated from components.json to bower.json

bower fetching d3
bower checking out d3#v3.1.10
bower warn Package d3 is still using the deprecated "component.json" file

title: Remove major class from axis ticks.
body: The major class is now obsolete with the removal of tick subdivision. Fixes #1485.

title: Fix #1483; time parsing with padding modifier.
d3.geo.circle: ensure coincident start/end points.
body:
Due to floating point rounding error, d3.geo.circle would sometimes miss
out the end point, which should be coincident with the start point.

Fixes #1476.

title: Fix clipExtent intersection sorting.
body:
The generic polygon clipping algorithm requires intersection points to
be sorted in a clockwise order around the clip edge.  Previously, the
intersection points for 2D clipping in d3_geo_clipView were sorted in a
counterclockwise direction in screen pixels, probably because the
flipped y-axis in screen pixels was not being taken into account.

title: Zoom Transitions
body:
Example: http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/06ecebbae5be9665e995

My biggest concern is dispatching zoom events on the initial application of the zoom behavior. This could easily break old code because the listener may not be ready to receive zoom events at the time the behavior is applied.

For example, it is common to apply the zoom behavior to a parent element that contains elements (such as axes) whose appearance will change during zoom. If the zoom behavior dispatches zoom events on its initial render, those child elements will not yet exist and the listener will crash. It’s easy to workaround this problem by registering the zoom behavior _after_ creating those child elements (per the above example), but this change would still break old code.

(The same argument applies to the brush on its initial render, though I think it will be less common for those brush events to break anything because commonly the brush is drawn on top of, and thus _after_, elements that are affected by the brush state.)

On the other hand, a nice side-effect of zoom events on initial application is that you eliminate code duplication between enter (the initial display) and update (in response to subsequent user events). But this is a negligible benefit as you could easily eliminate that code duplication by calling the zoom event listener explicitly on enter.

Potential fixes:
1. We could defer dispatch of events on application one tick by using d3.timer. This would guarantee that child elements have been created, however it is undesirable because it would cause flickering on the initial display.
2. We could not emit zoom events (and likewise brush events) when the zoom behavior is initially applied (and likewise whenever the brush is applied via selection.call). However, this would arguably be inconsistent with the automatic emission of events during transitions, and would require the caller to do more work during initialization.
3. We could special-case just the first application of the zoom behavior (and likewise the brush) to not emit events. But, this feels like an overly specialized fix.

title: Fix brush rounding.
body:
The use of floor appeared to cause minor inconsistencies in the position
of brush edges for different positions along a scale.  I believe floor
was originally used to ensure the brush would display more crisply.

Using round would be an alternative fix.  However, removing any kind of
rounding in pixel-space ensures that transitioning an extent (set in
data-space) will finish with the correct extent, determined by inverting
the pixel-space extent.

Of course, there may be a small precision error introduced by inverting
the pixel-space extent, which we may also want to address anyway, in
which case I suppose we could still use round.

title: 3.3 “Haleakalā”
body:
- [x] decide whether brush should dispatch events automatically during selection / transition (see discussion in #1461)
- [x] decide whether brush should store pre-transition state via closure or DOM (element.**chart**) [verdict: DOM]

- [x] add d3.pairs?
- [x] add d3.geo.compose, or reconsider how to combine custom transforms and viewport clipping… feels like d3.geo.identity is a bit of a misnomer since the only reason it exists (versus just using null) is to apply viewport clipping to an identity transform. but sometimes you want to apply that to a custom transform, and it feels cumbersome to do that currently [verdict: no d3.geo.compose for now, but rename d3.geo.identity to d3.geo.clipExtent]
- [x] fix #1434 (time.nice and time.ticks)

title: Fix #1453 - spurious interpolate when clean.
body: It looks to me like the d3_geo_clip polygonEnd check is assuming that if there are no clipped segments that the input polygon is outside (and possibly surrounding) the viewport. However, the clipped segments can also be empty when the polygon is completely inside the viewport, in which case the listener was already sent the input polygon (clean & 1). This check prevents additional interpolation when there was no intersection.

title: Fix #1420 - regression with degenerate log ticks.
body: Commit 59554738 broke the check for a degenerate domain; this restores the original check and adds a test to verify this behavior.

title: Avoid binding multiple touch listeners for zoom.
body:
For a two-finger pinch, if two touchstart events fire, this results in
two touchmove and touchend listeners.  The first will have a single
location in the locations variable, but its touchmove listener will
fire with two touches, causing it to fail due to not finding the
location of the second touch.

If the first listener fires before the second, this exception breaks
touch zooming (as no further listeners will be called), but the order is
undefined so may be browser/device dependent (for reproducing the bug).

Since zooming only ever involves a single gesture at a time, it makes
more sense to only have one listener of each type at a time, unlike
dragging, which involves multiple drag gestures at once.

title: Fix #1407 - transition.filter crashes on empty.
body: Also remove unneeded third argument to d3_transition since transition.time is now stored on the per-node transition object.

title: Remove mouse listeners from intended target.
Fix #1402 - transition callback order.
body: Rather than registering new timers, reassign the transition’s timer callback in-place such that the order of callbacks for transitions is always prioritized based on when the transition was created.

title: Fix panning for native Android 4.1 browser.
body:
This particular browser appears to fire a mousemove event as well as the
usual touch events.

The zoom behaviour adds a mousemove listener to reset translate0 to null
(so that scrolling the mouse wheel records a new translate0 vector).
However, the translate0 variable is also used to record initial touch
vectors on touchstart.

The fix uses a different variable to record initial touch vectors, since
in theory it might be possible to fire mousewheel events and touch
events simultaneously.

title: Remove symmetric Math.log.
body: Since Math.log is a monotonic function for positive values, we can safely remove the Math.log from both sides of the comparison. The reason Math.log was used previously is that this is an estimate of error (the log difference between the desired number of ticks and the actual number of ticks).

title: Suggested modification to selection.data
Use d3.rgb for categorical scales.
body: Now that d3.interpolateRgb (and by extension, d3.scale.linear) returns color instances for color interpolation, it seems more consistent to use d3.rgb for categorical scales, as well.

title: rgb.brighter 0 values not being incremented.
body: When any of the rgb values are 0 the if statement will be false and the value wont be incremented.

title: Fix #1373 - suppress touchstart on drag.
body:
This is not ideal because it disables clicking on draggable links, but as we are forced to suppress the touchstart event (before any movement) in order to disable touch-to-drag or pinch-to-zoom, I think this is the only option. Or, we might dispatch a synthetic click event if the touchstart is prevented.

This pull request also fixes the bug where touchend in d3.behavior.zoom calls touchstart, which was causing two quick touchend events to be misinterpreted as a dbltap.

title: Preserve user provided extent when resizing
body:
Currently, if a brush is created or updated with a user provided extent, all extent values may be modified even if only a single drag handle is adjusted.  This makes it difficult to use the returned brush extent when the initially set values are significant (e.g. if a brush is used as a time slider and the user adjusts the end time, we don't expect the start time to change).

Instead of clearing the entire cached extent any time one of the brush edges is moved, only the modified value should be cleared from the cached extent.  Then when getting a new extent, only the required values should be recalculated.

This example demonstrates the issue: http://bl.ocks.org/tschaub/5962208

title: Remove redundant Sizzle.uniqueSort call
body: Sizzle always returns unique elements in document order. If it doesn't, that is a bug that should be reported to Sizzle.

title: Fix axis for scales that don’t define ticks.
body:
In addition to ordinal scales, quantile, quantize and threshold scales don’t define a ticks method. Unlike ordinal scales, however, these quantitative scales also don’t define a rangeBand method, so the axis was crashing trying to render these scales. This fixes #1367 by checking for the required rangeBand method rather than assuming scales without a ticks method define a rangeBand.

Note, however, that even with this change you probably still want to define tick values explicitly when using one of these scales with an axis. That’s because each tick in the axis represents a span of values in the domain; you can use the invertExtent method to get the span for each tick value.

title: Color interpolators return color instances.
body: Fixes #1029. Previously, these interpolators returned RGB hexadecimal strings, as the intent was for the color to be used to set attributes and styles. However, since #333, all colors return RGB hexadecimal strings when coerced to a string, so we can get the equivalent behavior by returning a color instance rather than a string. Returning a color instance is also more useful in the case where additional color manipulation (such as brighter/darker) is desired.

title: By default, enter-insert before updating sibling.
body: Fixes #744. This implements a default _before_ selector such that when entering elements are inserted (e.g., `selection.enter().insert("div")`), they are inserted before the next following sibling in the update selection, if any. This change does not affect the behavior of append, so as to preserve backwards-compatibility, and likewise does not affect the behavior of insert on non-enter selections.

title: Use linear segments for basis interpolation ends.
body: The first and last segment of a line interpolated using basis (B-spline) interpolation are necessarily linear. WebKit appears to have a bug where linear Bézier segments do not compute tangents correctly (presumably because the control points are coincident with an end point, and the angle of a zero-length vector is undefined). We can workaround this browser bug by using linear segments for the start and end.

title: Accept function for selection append and insert.
body:
Like selection.select, selection.append and selection.insert can now accept a function which returns a node. This facilitates appending or inserting elements whose name is computed from data, or appending elements that were created previously (such as removed elements or elements from a pool).

There has been [much discussion](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/pull/732#issuecomment-7436280) regarding whether the function should return the name of the element or the element itself. Returning a name is less work for the caller, but only supports creating new elements. Returning a name is more consistent with how D3 defines attribute values, but D3 does not allow attribute names to be specified as functions. So, it seemed better to opt for consistency with selection.select and selection.selectAll, which accept functions that return elements. Of course, you can still pass a function to selection.select, selection.selectAll or selection.each to accomplish the same thing, but using selection.append is more intuitive.

Related #4 #311 #724 #732 #734 #961 #1031 #1271.

title: Allow pack.radius to be specified as constant.
Remove axis.tickSubdivide. Fixes #1115.
body: An alternative to #1350.

title: Replace axis.tickSubdivide with axis.minorTicks. Fixes #1115.
body:
I’m not sure yet if this is a good idea, but it does seem more flexible than subdividing ticks in the axis that were computed by the scale. The problem with the simpler fix of #1115 is that the axis can’t force the scale to generate two extra major ticks—those ticks could be irregularly-spaced, as is the case with a time scale.

So, rather than trying to subdivide ticks uniformly, the axis exposes a way of creating minor ticks. For example, you could have major ticks using d3.time.weeks, and minor ticks using d3.time.days. Any minor tick that is also a major tick is only displayed as a major tick. 

One weakness with this approach is that it assumes there is a scale.ticks method, so there’s no way to create minor ticks for an ordinal scale or other scale that doesn’t support generating ticks. Likewise, although you can specify major ticks explicitly using axis.tickValues, I haven’t exposed an axis.minorTickValues method.

This pull request retains the axis.tickSubdivide method as a no-op, so that existing code will not break. However, this means you need to update code to call axis.minorTicks if you want minor ticks displayed. It’s possible in some cases to generate suitable minor tick arguments, and thus have better backwards-compatibility, but since it’s not possible in all cases this seems like a reasonable option. Alternatively we could defer this until 4.0?

Lastly, my other reservation is whether the axis needs an explicit concept of major and minor ticks at all. It seems like clients could specify only major ticks, and then use post-selection to mark a subset of them as minor ticks.

title: Limit transform interpolation to transition.attr.
body:
D3’s transform interpolator is designed for SVG transforms; unlike CSS3 transforms, SVG transforms do not have units and are limited to 2D. This commit limits transform interpolation to transition.attr, so that it only applies to SVG transforms and not CSS3 transforms which are assigned via style. Thus, if transition.style is used to interpolate the transform style, the default string interpolator will now be used.

Note that string interpolation of CSS3 transforms is still likely to break; you should use CSS3 transitions instead. Fixes #1323.

title: Add currency support to d3.format. Fixes #777.
body:
You can now prefix the locale’s currency symbol. For example:

``` js
d3.format("+$,.2f")(-2.5e5) // -$250,000.00
```

This implementation is limited in that it does not support currencies where the symbol should appear after the value (e.g., "250,000.00 €" as in fr_FR). And d3.format currently only supports a single locale. But it’s a start.

title: Fix clip for closed polygons.
body:
This pull request fixes a long standing bug (#443) by making polygon.clip work on closed polygons; previously it only worked on open polygons. The other polygon methods, area and centroid, already work on both open and closed polygons.

This pull request also changes d3.geom.polygon to use a prototype rather than creating every method as a closure. This will potentially break callers that assumed polygon methods were bound to the object instance, but this was never documented as an API guarantee so I am comfortable making this change in a patch release. (Also, the majority of examples using polygon.clip should now be using the more-convenient voronoi.clipExtent.)

title: Implement inertial drag
body:
Please see the example: http://bl.ocks.org/pjanik/5872514
Recently I needed such feature and implemented it in my application, but then I came up with the idea that it can be easily generalized. Inertial drag is quite popular nowadays.

I'm creating pull request so you can easily review the code, but of course I'm open for discussion. 
Do you find it useful?

Note that I'm not very familiar with d3 codebase, so I'm happy to fix implementation details, style, add some tests etc. in case of need.

@paulsputer needed to format a subset of an object’s properties for each row, so I suggested using csv.formatRows(rows.map(…)).  However, this does not output field headings, and it would be cleaner to use csv.format(rows, accessor) for symmetry with parsing rather than having to roll your own.

title: Restore preventDefault, but use tabindex to focus the parent element.
body:
Work-in-progress. Supersedes #1322. Should fix #1321 #1288 #1099.

Tasks:
- [ ] Applying the drag behavior, zoom behavior or brush should set the tabindex attribute and outline style on the nearest HTML ancestor element (the ownerSVGElement when used within SVG, and the current element when used within HTML).
- [ ] If the tabindex attribute is already set, it should be preserved? What about the outline style? It might be safe to ignore this possibility.
- [x] The mousedown event should be cancelled (using preventDefault and stopPropagation).
- [x] The touchstart event should _not_ be cancelled for the drag behavior, as this disables draggable links. (Canceling mousedown does not prevent click, but canceling touchstart effectively does.)

body:
This allows behaviours and d3.svg.brush to be used together easily.

Also, only bind relevant event listeners on brush touchstart; a
mousemove event was being triggered on mobile Safari causing the brush
to jump briefly on touchstart, e.g. when viewing:

  http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/raw/1667367/

Fixes #1321.

title: brush.clamp: return null if there are no scales.
body:
Similarly, if there are no scales, setting a clamp does nothing.

For consistency with brush.extent.

title: Fixes d3_time_interval to return regular time intervals
body:
The d3_time_interval function used "number" in order to implement steps,
which led to incorrect behavior. For example, the "number" function for
months returned date.getMonth(), which is 0 for January, hence if the
step input to range was greater than 12, an array containing all the
January 1 dates between start and end would be returned. Because number
was only used (incorrectly) in the range function I've gone through the
time implementations and removed the specific cases.

title: Add xExtent and yExtent to d3.behavior.zoom (fixes #1084)
body:
These limit all actions to ensure the domain of the corresponding scale always stays within the given extent. As well as panning, zooming actions may also be limited in the zoom-out direction. If more than one of scaleExtent, xExtent and yExtent are provided, the effective bottom end of the scale extent will be the most restrictive of the three.

If scaleExtent and x/yExtent cannot be satisfied simultaneously (i.e. the lower scale limit implied by x/yExtent is above the scaleExtent), then x/yExtent will take priority.

Simple example: http://bl.ocks.org/mhsmith/5732011
Example with discontinuous and log scales: http://bl.ocks.org/mhsmith/5734904

title: Use relative error for intersections. Fixes #1075.
Add graticule.multipoint.
body: Includes all intersection points and endpoints of the graticule.  Useful for showing Tissot’s indicatrices, for example.

Fixes #1288, #1099.

will be more substantial in other browsers, and it should reduce garbage

Benchmark, drawing one small circle (10,000 samples):

Old: 0.091ms.
New: 0.084ms.

Fixes #1258.

More importantly, we no longer depend on a specific commit ID.

Fix d3.geo.bounds for null geometries.
body:
This fixes an error that would be thrown if no defined bounds were
found.  It also ensures that undefined bounds are returned as
[[NaN, NaN], [NaN, NaN]], for consistency with d3.extent, which returns
[undefined, undefined] for an empty array.

Fixes #1154.

title: Partial fix for #1196 and d3.time.day in BST.
body: While note as complete a solution as #1197, this fixes the immediate problem of d3.time.day not returning midnights when on British Summer Time (BST), due to the UK being on permanent BST during 1970.

title: Initialize points array when using custom x() or y() functions
body:
Points was undefined and causing errors to be thrown when push was called on it.

This could actually be improved slightly by preallocating an array of n elements since we already know how many we have.

title: Expose access to request.responseType in xhr
body:
Also, don't always prefer XDomainRequest in a cross domain request.

This allows the caller to specify the response value type where available,
such as blob or json, which can greatly accelerate dealing with certain
types of data.

A cursory search suggests that IE's XDomainRequest does not use responseType,
so the caller will need to check the resulting type if a specific
responseType is required for a cross domain request.

IE's XDomainRequest also doesn't appear to have many other aspects available
in XMLHttpRequest, such as responseXML, currently used in d3.xml.

So a feature test is done on XMLHttpRequest to see if it supports CORS,
rather than always preferring IE's XDomainRequest where a cross domain
request is needed.

title: Allow calling Selection.append( function(datum, index){...} )
body: Relatively small improvement to Selection.append function to allow passing data-dependent function instead of predefined string.

title: If xhr.response errors, callback with error.
body: Fixes #1263. Previously, if d3.json was used to load invalid JSON, a SyntaxError would be thrown. Now an error is reported to the callback instead, in the same manner as if a network error occurred. This allows the caller to handle the invalid response, rather than throwing an asynchronous error.

title: Include an API for SVG transform attributes
body:
d3-transform makes it easy to define and reuse functions that produce transform attribute strings for SVG elements. Using d3-transform reduces repetition, allows you to compose multiple transforms, and eliminates ugly string-interpolation from transform attr calls.

More info and docs here: https://github.com/trinary/d3-transform#readme

This PR includes that transform API and adapts the code and tests in that repo to fit d3's existing structure and style.

title: Add argument to d3.xhr. fixes #1260.
body:
Fixes race condition that exists where the xhr.onload fires before
xhr.response has had a change to be set. This causes d3_json for example
to not get called.

The approach is to add another argument to the d3.xhr constructor. This method can then call xhr.response([the new callback]).

title: Accept string as log scale tickFormat.
body: Commit d0441e6 introduced specifying the linear scale tick format as a string, as by `axis.ticks(10, "%")`. This extends this pattern to log scales for consistency.

title: Define rangeBand in context of rangePoints.
body: Previously, the rangeBand was zero when rangePoints was used. Now it returns the size of the step between points. Fixes #584.

title: add nest.each function
Redesigned d3.geo.albersUsa.
body: This commit changes the albersUsa projection so that it uses a custom projection stream rather than a custom projection function. The projection stream passes geometry to all three constituent projections, which are then clipped to their respective viewports. The result is that geometry that appears in multiple projections (such as a graticule) is now rendered correctly in each, with clipping! In addition, the inverse projection is much easier to compute because the viewport regions of each projection are explicitly defined.

title: Allow call() on selections following enter()
body:
The following fails with error "Uncaught TypeError: Object [object Array] has no method 'call'".  I'm using Chrome 26. 

``` javascript
d3.select('body').data([0]).enter().call(function () { alert('called!'); });
```

I'm new to d3, so this fix may be dangerous in some way I don't understand.

title: enable configuration of a different window object
body:
Presently when running in node.js, d3 creates it's own window object to operate on. While initially convenient this makes it quite difficult to have independent flows of execution all using d3. This change enables the creation of new d3 instances which are bound to provided windows. My driving motivation is that I want to use d3 to build my views on both the client and the server. On the server I need each request to have an isolated environment. Here is an example of using the proposed `d3.env` function with jsdom ``` javascript jsdom.env( "
" , function(err, window){ var d3 = require('d3').env(window) d3.select('.wibble') .classed('wibble', false) .classed('wobble', true) console.log(window.document.innerHTML) //
} ) ``` As well as allowing for isolated windows this enables the use of alternative DOM implementations. As an example for my own purposes I believe [domino](https://github.com/fgnass/domino) is more appropriate. ``` javascript var domino = require('domino') , win = domino.createWindow('
') var d3 = require('d3').env(win) d3.select('#foo').classed('dimdom', true) console.log(win.document.innerHTML) //
``` Grateful for you thoughts sammy

title: Fix #1247 - more robust interpolation, again.
body:
This removes the use of interpolateString if the start and end values passed to
d3.interpolate are different types; the interpolation behavior should be based
solely on the end value. Now if you interpolate an undefined attribute (the
empty string) to a number, it will use number interpolation as expected.

This also fixes interpolateString such that it always returns a string, even if
both the start and end value are coercible to numbers.

title: Add semicolon delimiter to d3.csv2
body:
In some countries it is very common to write the decimal point as a
comma instead of period, even the default csv file generated from
softwares like Excel and Numbers in countries like Brazil uses
semicolon instead of comma.

I've taken the same approach to name (csv2) as R.

title: restoring original children in d3.layout.hierarchy

title: Preserve domains exactly.
body:
Fixes #1241. With d3.scale.pow, d3.scale.sqrt and d3.scale.log, the underlying
implementation is a linear scale. Due to the transformation a linear domain and
the limits of floating-point precision, the reported domain could differ
slightly from what was set. Now, the set domain is preserved exactly.

title: require('d3') on serverside does not initialize global object's window or document properties.
body: `global` object does not have reference to `window` and `document` before `require('/globals')` so the forEach statements are pointless and harmful because global does not yet have a pointer to window and document Removing them would fix the issue that global object does not have window and document properties.

title: Fix d3.svg.brush IE bug
body:
I add a code to solve #1018

This fix only put overflow:hidden on svg element when it's created.

Notice that only append.js and insert.js was modified. It's necessary run make. (I work with windows and I can't run Makefile)

title: Fix time tests by adding Date to sandbox.
body:
Since tests are now run in their own sandbox, assert.deepEqual was not properly testing the returned Date objects for equality, as they weren't instances of the same Date class used by the test itself, causing type inference to fail.

It was always returning true, even for different dates!

An alternative fix would be to define our own assert.dateEqual, which would compare .getTime() directly instead of using type inference.

title: d3.geo.bounds: antimeridian and inflection points.
body:
The behaviour of d3.geo.bounds has been modified slightly, such that the
minimum and maximum longitudes denote minimum and maximum meridians when
going from left to right in a standard equirectangular projection.

If the maximum longitude is in fact numerically smaller than the
meridian, this simply means that the bounds cross the antimeridian.

This fixes several issues:
- The bounding box is now a true minimum-width bounding box.
- Line segments that cross the antimeridian are now correctly handled.
- Similarly, polygons that cross the antimeridian are now correctly
  handled.

Secondly, inflection points are now detected, so that the latitudinal
range is extended in the case where the great arc contains the great
circle’s inflection point.

Lastly, support for polygons has been improved, e.g. those that wind
around the poles, and those that have a counter-clockwise winding order.

Note that as part of the winding order detection, the performance of
d3.geo.area had to be reduced somewhat (by as much as 25%).  This is
because the trick to avoid atan2 calls fails for winding order detection
in the case where a counter-clockwise area strays into a positive
quadrant.  We can reinstate the trick for area-only calculations in
future; I think correct winding order detection is more important at the
moment.

See #1154 (remaining: handling of null-like features and geometries).

title: Fix null transform attribute warning in Firefox.
body:
Strictly speaking, the transform attribute should never be set to null;
it should be set to "translate(0)" for the identity transform, or it
should be removed using removeAttribute("transform").

Setting this attribute to null causes a warning to appear in Firefox:

  "Unexpected value null parsing transform attribute."

This occurs when using d3.transform(null), e.g. to interpolate to or
from a non-existent transform attribute (null).

This fix checks whether the value is null, and if so, returns an
identity transform.

title: Fix #749 for getting and removing tweens.
Allow hue, chroma or saturation to be undefined.
body:
In HSL space, grayscale colors can now have undefined hue rather than assuming a
hue of 0°; likewise black and white can have undefined saturation rather than
assuming 0%. In HCL space, black can now have undefined hue and chroma. (For
non-black grayscale colors, including white, hue and chroma are implied by the
D65 standard referent.)

When interpolating between colors with undefined hue, saturation or chroma, the
defined value is used when available. For example, when interpolating from black
to blue in HCL space, the intermediate colors are now dark blues (#241178)
rather than dark purples (#600054).

Fixes #833.

title: Add scale.quantize.invert
body:
I think it'll be nice to be able to invert quantize scale.
## Use Case Scenario

In a visualization, I am using a quantize scale to map a period of time into several segments. The scale gets a `Date` object, and outputs which segment the date belongs to. Now I want to visually mark the time segments, therefore I have to know when each of the time segments start and end. I think the scale should be able to provide such information.
## Documentation

**quantize.invert(y)**

Returns the interval in the domain, represented in two-element array, for the corresponding value in the range _y_. For any valid _y_ in the range, any _x_ within the interval [`quantize.invert(y)[0]`, `quantize.invert(y)[1]`) should satisfy `quantize(x) === y`.

If _y_ is not unique in the range, the function will return the first extent in the domain that maps to _y_. If _y_ is not in the range of the quantize scale, the function will return a meaningless extent.
## Usage Example

``` javascript
var q = d3.scale.quantize()
  .domain([0, 10])
  .range(d3.range(5));

q(2);  // => 1
q(3);  // => 1
q(3.9);  // => 1
q(4);  // => 2

q.invert(1);  // => [2, 4]
q.invert(2);  // => [4, 6]
```

title: Support scale.nice(step) with a custom stepsize
Fix Firefox time interval bug for Europe/London.
body:
d3.time.day should always return midnights.  However, Firefox doesn't
return midnight for the following:

```
var d = new Date(1970, 0);
d.setFullYear(2011, 8, 22);
// Thu Sep 22 2011 01:00:00 GMT+0100 (BST)
```

Chrome and Node.js return:

```
// Thu Sep 22 2011 00:00:00 GMT+0100 (BST)
```

This is because `new Date(1970, 0)` has different daylight saving
behaviour in the two browsers.

Chrome: Thu Jan 01 1970 00:00:00 GMT+0000 (GMT)
Firefox: Thu Jan 01 1970 01:00:00 GMT+0100 (BST)

In fact, Firefox is more correct!  The UK was on permanent BST from
February 1968 until October 1971.  This seemingly minor difference in
interpretation results in non-midnight times being returned for all day
intervals and other intervals that use d3.time.day internally.

The fix forces midnight to always be returned.

Fixes #1196.

title: Enforce minimum sample interval for resampling.
body:
The minimum sample interval is somewhat arbitrarily set to 16 × δ, where
δ is the Douglas–Peucker threshold.  This fixes cases where resampling
stops too early due to the perpendicular distance being below the
threshold; particularly for points that are far apart and whose
great-circle arc is projected to an S-shape.  The midpoint lies along a
straight line, failing the Douglas–Peucker check, but further resampling
produces an S-shape.

Ideally, resampling should also detect cases where an intermediate point
does not need to be drawn, i.e. where there truly is a straight line.
This fix causes points to be drawn at the minimum sample interval, and
thus may degrade performance slightly due to drawing redundant points.

Fixes #1162.

title: Optimize tick function in Force layout
body:
For the default value of alpha (0.1), the tick function is executed 298 times.

If there are no nodes (unlikely; nobody is going to start the force layout without nodes) or all nodes removed in the course of animation (possible), there is no need to continue ticking anymore.

Added a check near the top of tick function to end ticking if the number of nodes is/becomes zero.

title: fix component support
body:
I'd like to use d3 as a [component](https://github.com/component/component). @visionmedia has created [component/d3](https://github.com/component/d3), but it is out of date, and generally keeping it up to date is non-sustainable since it involves human intervention. So let's make this repo a component.

I noticed there is a [component.json](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/master/component.json) file in the repo, but it wont work since a couple things are missing. Particularly:
- `main` needs to be in `scripts` also. (see [spec](https://github.com/component/component/wiki/Spec#main))
- `d3` needs to be exported in [d3.js](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/master/d3.js) so that it can be `require()`ed later.

This PR fixes the issues mentioned above, but it might be missing a few things.
- I'm not sure about the [globals.js](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/master/globals.js)
- the `module.exports` added detection at the bottom of [d3.js](https://github.com/danmilon/d3/blob/bc9932af96fbe8d88655849705cd5e40588c2e59/d3.js#L8440-L8442) might not be desired

Suggestions are welcome.

title: Fix for #1005 - fix click suppression after dragend in cases where click doesn't fire.
body:
Fixes Issue #1005 for both behavior.zoom and behavior.drag

This fixes (which we're using at appneta to fix this issue in our app for both zoom and drag) cases when code intended to suppress superfluous click events on dragend causes a later click (anywhere on the page) to be absorbed.

Since the undesired click event should fire immediately after dragend, before returning to the JS event loop, the 0ms setTimeout where we clear the handler would only ever fire after the click event.  This should also take place fast enough that most human users would never make a subsequent click before the setTimeout fires.

This is a bit hacky as noted in https://github.com/mbostock/d3/issues/1005#issuecomment-15592805, but is probably less complicated than trying to discern cases/browsers/versions where the click does and does not fire.

title: selection.insert() now accepts before argument as function

title: Allow setting the type of constraint to use when dragging a brush
body:
Add a `dragConstraints` method to **brush** that excepts the following options:
- _closed_ The default and constrains the extent to be entirely within the range
- _open_ Constrians the extent to where it can can go just outside the range
- _halfopen_ Constrains the extent to where half of it can go outside the range
- _loose_ No constraints, can drag the extent well beyond the range

I specifically needed the `halfopen` setting because my graph is a list of reports and whichever report is in the center of the range is _selected_. So I needed the ability to drag the extent halfway past the range to allow for this:

I have an example of this here: http://bl.ocks.org/jisaacks/5271235 you will notice if you make a brush and drag it all the way to the left or right it will allow you to keep dragging until the beginning/end of the graph is in the center.

Currently in D3 there was no way to specify this behavior.

I added the other settings for completeness.

This features adds about 1.3kB to the minified library (comparing the results of `make`).

_NB. I went ahead and implemented this approach, though I'm still open to switching to the other approaches if so desired._

title: Fix closed rings generated by clipping.
body:
After intersecting a polygon with a clip region, it's possible for one
or more of the resulting visible segments to be a closed ring.  This
occurs when the first and last points in a segment are coincident (or
close enough to be coincident).

If the clipping algorithm attempts to rejoin these segments, first it
orders intersection points along the clip edge, and the subsequent
interpolation direction depends on this order.  However, the order of
coincident points is ambiguous, hence “flickering” may occur if the
order of two coincident swaps around, causing interpolation to alternate
between taking the longer and shorter ways around the clip edge.

See #1095.

title: Layered layout
body:
This checkin includes:
- Basic layered layout (layer.js)
- Layered layout test case (layer-test.js)
## Use case

Sometimes it is desirable to draw a graph structure as a tree.  The nature of a graph structure makes it hard to represent it generically as a tree.  If we annotate the structure with "levels" we can render it as a hierarchy.  This is useful in cases where you have a structure in which a child node can have many parents.
## Example

![graphpreview](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1201248/184212/e208af60-7cd1-11e2-9dd2-8c5f1b13e138.jpg)

``` javascript
{
  nodes: [
    {name: "Level1a", level: 1}/*0*/,
    {name: "Level2a", level: 2}/*1*/, {name: "Level2b", level: 2},/*2*/
    {name: "Level3a", level: 3}/*3*/, {name: "Level3b", level: 3}/*4*/
  ],
  links: [
    {source: 0, target: 1}, // Level1a -> Level2a
    {source: 0, target: 2}, // Level1a -> Level2b
    {source: 1, target: 3}, // Level2a -> Level3a
    {source: 2, target: 3}, // Level2b -> Level3a
    {source: 1, target: 4}, // Level2a -> Level3b
    {source: 2, target: 4} // Level2b -> Level3b
  ]
}
```

title: Allow d3.map to be used with d3.nest’s map.
body:
You can now pass a map type to d3.nest’s map function. For example, if you pass
d3.map as the second argument to nest.map(array, type), the returned value will

title: Added Variance and Corrected Standard Deviation to core array functions
body:
D3 already has functions to get the `max`, `min`, `mean` etc. of an array. What is missing is the calculation of the variance and standard deviation. For that I needed an other library like jStats, but I think it's very handy to have them available right from D3.

```
d3.sd([1,2,3,4,5]) => 1.5811388300841898
d3.variance([1,2,3,4,5]) => 2.5
```

This makes sense if you e.g. want to add the sd to a chart or calculate a gaussian standard deviation curve.

title: Allow passing class names as functions to `classed()`
body:
This patch allows to set class names based on bound data. I often found myself adding classes based on data properties, such as `status`, `country_id`, etc.

For example, let's have a data set:

```
var data = [
  { value: 1.2, status: 'finished' },
  { value: 3.4, status: 'initializing' },
]
```

Without this patch, the only way how to add classes based on the `status` property (which I am aware of) is to explicitely list them:

```
d3.select('body')
  .selectAll('div')
  .data( data )
  .enter()
    .append('div')
    .classed({
      finished:     function(d,i) { return d.status == 'finished' },
      initializing: function(d,i) { return d.status == 'initializing' }
    })
```

With this patch, it's possible to pass a function to the `classed()` method, which will be passed the corresponding data and evaluated:

```
d3.select('body')
  .selectAll('div')
  .data( data )
  .enter()
    .append('div')
    .classed( function(d,i) { return d.status} )
```

Not sure how this use-case is common, but I find it a lot in my projects, and this patch makes the code much more succinct and nice.

---

Notes:
- Added tests to the `test/core/selection-classed-test.js`
- Slightly refactored the code within the `d3_selection_classed()` function, introduced the `classNameManipulator` function to evade code duplication (`name.trim().split ...`)
- Will happily revert this refactoring or rewrite the code as per any suggestions

title: Rebind returns target when the source returns itself
body:
The logic is as follows:  If a rebound function returns the source object, we should return the target object, even when no arguments were supplied.

Example:   If I rebind a dispatch object to a target object and call a dispatch function with no argument, it will return the target, not the dispatch object, allowing for proper chaining.

title: Sort null nodes at the end.
body:
Previously, null nodes were passed to the comparator and were indistinguishable
from non-null nodes with no bound data. For consistency with other selection
operators that skip null nodes, it seems preferrable to put null nodes at the
end of the selection rather than passing them to the comparator. Fixes #881.

title: Inject global d3 var
body:
It is nice if one can move the global variable for a library to another namespace and then delete the global. For instance, with jQuery I can move $ to MyAppNamespace.$, then delete window.$. jQuery will continue to work after this.

d3 does not continue to work if I attempt the same thing. This is because the d3 global variable is declared within the main function body as a global, and is not injected. With the simple changes here I am free to reassign the global d3 variable into my own namespace.

title: Allow custom coordinate space while dragging
body:
Problem: when you modify grandparent's transform during drag callback you get discontinuity in d3.event data. This leads to poor experience during dragging as described here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13078535/stuttering-drag-when-using-d3-behavior-drag-and-transform

Solution: allow specification of custom node which will be taken as base coordinate space for the drag session.

In our case of modification grandparent's transform, this usage fixes the issue:

```
d3.behavior.drag().base(function(target) { return target.parentNode.parentNode; });
```

remained broken was Firefox, who adopted the newer W3C "wheel" event standard.
This commit removes the old div hack, and does better support detection to
determine the most standards-based approach to listening for wheel events.

title: Allow type conversion in dsv.parse
body:
This is a stab at addressing #387, by adding an optional `types` argument to `dsv.parse`, which can either be an array or an object depending on whether the functions in `types` should be applied by position or name. (Although if you want to do the former, it seems better to just use `dsv.parseRows` directly.)

Problems:
1. `dsv.parse` was optimized in 2358fd0fb43d74cb72ddc4dd2218ab9153d0af02; this makes it slower again, even when the type conversion isn't used. I have created a [basic benchmark](https://gist.github.com/02033970558429c73626) for the behaviour using this function before optimization, after optimization, and after this change.
2. The interface may not be ideal. For numbers, I have been using `parseInt` and `parseFloat`, which could be wrapped as something like `d3.csv.int`, but then that's no shorter. For dates and times, `d3.time.format` already seems perfect to me.
3. As a corollary, because this accepts functions, it isn't restricted to just converting types. That seems like a duplication of effort, given that this is adding another layer of indirection: it calls another function from within `o`, which in turn calls the functions passed in `types`, and the only reason for not using `dsv.parseRows` is convenience. It's also possible for people to do unexpected things with it.
4. There is no type inference, which is mentioned in passing in the original issue.

title: Optimise d3.geo.area.
body:
This incorporates two enhancements:
1. A simpler formulation for the area of a spherical triangle with one
   vertex at the south pole.
2. Instead of calling atan2 for every point, we use the identity:
    ∑ arg(z) = arg(∏ z),
   where z is a complex number, and only call atan2 once for each
   polygon, instead opting for a cheaper complex number multiplication
   for each point.

This is around 3x faster than the old implementation as measured by the
included benchmark.

title: Added d3.svg.transform, a way to construct SVG transform specifications
body:
Constructing SVG transform specifications currently involves some somewhat ugly string concatenation - e.g.

.attr("transform", function(d) { return "transform(" + d.x + "," + d.y + ") rotate(" + d.r + ")"; })

This diff adds d3.svg.transform, a builder for SVG transform strings.
We can replace the above code by the simpler code:

.attr("transform", function(d) { return d3.svg.transform().translateX(d.x).translateY(d.y).rotate(d.r); })

or

.attr("transform", function(d) { return d3.svg.transform().translate([d.x, d.y]).rotate(d.r); })

See tests for other examples.  Note that this does not implement the full SVG spec at http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/coords.html#TransformAttribute,
only a subset determined by looking at how transforms are used in other D3 projects.

Edwin de Jong

title: Improve Polygon clipping.
body:
1. We no longer perform an equality check on GeoJSON polygon endpoints, since we know that the first and last points should be equal.
2. However, there are special cases where a polygon just touches the clip edge, generating two coincident intersection points.  Here we avoid generating a coincident point, and continue as normal.
3. Another special case is where we have coincident intersection points e.g. due to a self-intersecting polygon.  Here we continue calculating the winding number as if this is a closed polygon (so we know whether to insert a polygon around the whole clip edge).

title: Improve Polygon clipping.
body:
Specifically, endpoints are no longer checked for equality, since precision errors can cause this check to fail.  In fact, we don't even care if the endpoints aren't equal; we just check for intersections instead.

title: Transition reselection.
body:
It is now possible to reselect elements with scheduled transitions and redefine associated tweens; this enables "post-selection" to customize the behavior of reusable components undergoing transitions, such as an axis. This commit also makes it much easier to sequence transitions.

Previously, a transition's tweens were stored privately by the transition and could only be accessed through the transition. This made it impossible to modify transitions created by components: the transition is not accessible externally, and cannot be reselected from the document. Consider the following snippet:

``` js
g.select(".x.axis")
    .call(xAxis)
  .selectAll("text")
    .attr("dy", null);
```

If `g` is a selection, then this code alters the appearance of the axis as expected. However, if `g` is a transition, then transition.selectAll creates a new concurrent transition, and now multiple tweens compete to set the "dy" attribute. Oy!

Under the new design, an element's scheduled tweens are stored semi-privately on the node (in the existing `node.__transition__`). Transition parameters can thus be reselected and modified by transitions that share the same id. If you now reselect a transitioning element, you modify the transition rather creating a competing transition; this should be less surprising and allow greater control.

As a side-effect of this change, it is no longer possible to schedule concurrent transitions on the same element, even with the same id: only one transition may be active on a given element at any time. (Note that you can still schedule multiple future transitions on the same element, and concurrent transitions on different elements.) For example, you could previously schedule overlapping transitions with different easing functions, delays or durations, provided you were careful to avoid conflict. This seems like a relatively obscure use-case compared to modifying a transition, so I believe this is a reasonable change.

This commit also changes transition.transition, such that the returned transition starts at the end of the originating transition, rather than overlapping. This makes it much easier to schedule sequenced transitions without the complexity of transition.each("end") and d3.select(this).

Also, transitions are now simply arrays of nodes, consistent with selections!

title: Better resampling for non-linear distortions.
body:
I've reinstated the original conditional for linear longitudinal interpolation, since the x \* x < ε conditional was not tight enough and hence caused glitches in projections that include the poles e.g. stereographic.

Back to solving the issue that was primarily noticeable in the Albers demo: graticules near the poles would not resample correctly. We made an assumption that a point mid-way along the connecting great arc is going to be approximately mid-way in pixel-space. This is a reasonable assumption in most cases, but there is an area of high instability near the poles, since a small change in distance could result in a large change in longitude, e.g. imagine a great arc going right over a pole, so the longitude will change greatly depending on which side of the pole you're on.

So the new fix is to see if the distance in pixel-space hardly changed at all, and in this case we attempt to interpolate again, mid-way to the new spherical coordinates. I think we can probably improve this even further by borrowing methods from standard root-finding techniques e.g. Newton–Raphson.

title: Fixed bug in treemap layout where treemap.children() would be ignored.

title: Add extra ring if polygon "surrounds" clip circle.
body:
For example, when using the stereographic projection with a large clip circle of 179°, a polygon surrounding the removed region of 1° radius effectively becomes inverted, such that its vertices define a hole within the large clip circle of 179°. So in this case, we need to insert an additional ring around the clip circle, going in the opposite direction to the inverted polygon, so that the default non-zero winding rule for fill (in both canvas and SVG) fills only the area between the clip edge and the polygon boundary.

The winding number calculation can be optimised using the 3D coordinates directly from the rotation step, rather than performing additional trig. calculations. (Likewise, other clipping operations can also work on 3D coordinates directly.)

Here is North America around the boundary of a stereographic projection:

![](http://www.jasondavies.com/tmp/stereo-clip.png)

title: projection.clipAngle.
body:
Still a few more things I want to do before this is _perfect_:
1. This includes my fix from the clip-complex branch. However, I'd like to try an alternative fix, which should be theoretically more robust (although I haven't managed to break the current fix yet!)
2. Both cutting and circle clipping fail to cope with the clip edge being completely subsumed by a polygon. This is important for the stereographic projection, for example. Should be straightforward to detect, and there are a few tricks to make it efficient as it's fairly rare for this to happen.
3. For non-90° clip angles, I need to detect the case where two endpoints are invisible, but there is an intermediate visible segment.

Optimisation ideas (can be done in a future release, potentially):
1. If we know we're visible, it's safe to start drawing immediately, until we see an intersection. At that point, we need to buffer up the remaining points and do the clever clipping stuff. But the common case is that things are either completely visible or not.
2. Optimise special case of clipAngle(90°): shouldn't need to convert to 3D vectors here.
3. Aside from 90°, the circle clipping uses 3D coordinates, so we can reuse the 3D conversion from the rotation here. (That is, if the rotation even converted to 3D in the first place.)

title: Inherit hue or saturation when interpolating to or from a monochrome color.
body:
Currently if you use `d3.interpolateHsl`or `d3.interpolateHcl` to blend a colour with black, you get red shades introduced. If you do the same with white, you get green shades.

For example, blue + black equals purple:

``` javascript
d3.interpolateHsl("#00f", "#000")(0.5)
//-> "#602060"
```

I would expect to see only shades of blue, from bright to dark.
Tweaking the input slightly gives us the expected result and shows where we're going wrong:

``` javascript
d3.interpolateHsl("#00f", "#001")(0.5)
//-> "#000088"
```

I think the hue value for black and white should be ignored for interpolation. This pull request fixes it for HSL and HCL and adds tests for RGB.

title: Only attempt to resample if distance < δ.
body:
This improves performance in the case where our input data is already of a high enough resolution, even when subject to distortion.

It’s unlikely that the Douglas–Peucker estimate (perpendicular distance) will be greater than δ if the two input points are already closer than 2δ.

title: Xhr2
body:
The new XHR2 framework looks great.  Here are a few additional ideas:
### xhr.post convenience function

Sending a POST request involves the following steps:
- Specify "POST" as a method in the open()
- Set the Content-Type header correctly 
- Ensure that the supplied data is a string.

Function xhr.post() simplifies the process by re-opening the request, determining  encoding / set header and stringify data if necessary.    Any type-specific methods  (d3.json/d3.text /d3.xml etc) can be switched to a POST by appending .post(data)  to the function call.

For example, the following GET

```
  d3.csv("http://localhost/test?a=1&b=2",fn)
```

can be changed to POST (url-encoded)

```
  d3.csv("http://localhost/test",fn)
    .post("a=1&b=2")
```

or POST (json-encoded)

```
  d3.csv("http://localhost/test",fn)
    .post({a:1,b:2})
```
### Accept Header moved to xhr.open

If mime has been defined at the top level, we use when xhr.open is called (in case it's called twice) as is the case when using type-specific methods  (d3.csv/d3.xml/d3.text etc) with a redefined xhr.open (i.e. xhr.post)
### sendTimeout

By putting a setTimeout(...,0) on the xhr.send and canceling/reinstating upon changes we eliminate the occurance of multiple firings of send  , allowing the send function to be anywhere in the chain, not just at the end.   In node this would be done under process.nextTick().   I realize this is unconventional, but it seems a very effective solution given how javascript sequences execution.
### xhr.open username/password

The XMLHttpRequest allows the specification of username /password.  This option is simply added to xhr.open and passed on.

title: More flexible XHR framework.
body:
This is backwards-compatible, yet adds numerous features to d3.xhr. You can now:
- Use standard node-style callbacks (fixes #473).
- Abort in-flight requests.
- Listen for progress events.
- Listen for load, error and abort events separately.
- Make POST requests (or any other method), including data.
- Set arbitrary request headers.
- Have multiple listeners on requests.

title: Xhr post

Here I have a different approach to the AJAX request.  I delay the execution to next tick, allowing the various parameters to be set by chaining (method, headers and data). 

By default the function is a GET request without any data  (backwards compatible)

The only place where this reduces performance, is in the non-standard case where charge was specifically set to ZERO: now the quadtree is constructed anyhow and the total charge is now calculated (absolute value sum), which is extra work for that situation; anybody else should observe about the same performance.

It is very useful for the user to be able to get access to the force layout's drag instance, so we can override/augment the drag behaviour easily (using namespaced events, f.e.); again http://bl.ocks.org/3616279 is one case where such ability is used to add a kind of 'pinning' behaviour for dragged nodes when SHIFT/CTRL has been pressed on mouse release.

title: force layout: properly UNSET the .fixed bits: user may be using further ...
