...bits and those should be kept intact.

(I use the force layout in several places where it was/is extremely handy to use the higher bits for my own augmentations, which depend on the internal 'if (node.fixed) { dont_move_node }' force.layout logic. 

One such example is http://bl.ocks.org/3616279 which is a layout which adds 'pinning' baheviour where nodes stick to the dragged-to location when you keep SHIFT or CTRL pressed when stopping the drag (when you try that gist, it has the known issue that it doesn't properly keep/release the pinned state; that's an irrelevant detail of that specific example.)

title: Add "*/*" to Accept header.
body:
This avoids a 406 error from servers that don't support a given mime type.

See [discussion](https://groups.google.com/d/topic/d3-js/41pT3nXdEVk/discussion).

title: force cluster example: fixed minor hull error ('hulls' --> 'hullset') + ...
body:
...augmented example, showing distance function based on collected node/group info + click on node to expand/collapse (toggle) instead of harder-to-perform dblclick.

(fix: the force example had two var hulls (one object, one array) in a single function. It works, but is not something you want others to copy.)

Now the force-cluster example shows a graphic identical to http://bl.ocks.org/3071239

title: Empty default enter() and exit() for all selections (previously undefined)
body: This allows for better consistancy among selection objects, with enter() exit() chains ignored if no new .data() has been defined for the selection.  Should be backwards compatible.

title: Fix for a leap year bug
body: Calling new d3_time(0, 01, 29) returns Mar 01, since 0 (1900) was not a leap year.

title: Adding y1 to default stackOut
body: SVG Rectangles start at top-left corner (x0,y1).  Providing y1 simplifies rendering and should be backwards compatable.

title: d3.dsv: make it easier to support streams.
body:
We include the current byte position of the end of the row as the third argument to the optional callback.

This allows streaming data to be easily parsed, as the next chunk can be computed using the penultimate byte position as an offset. You can also check for all cases of EOL delimiters at the chunk boundary to avoid re-parsing the last row in a chunk in these cases.

_Edit: removed special null behaviour._

title: Minor simplifications.
body: Removes a few extraneous parentheses that aren't needed due to operator precedence.

title: Fix use of "dx" in examples.
body:
Compared to WebKit, this seems to be handled differently by current versions of Firefox and Opera, [perhaps due to an ambiguity in the spec](http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-svg/2011Dec/0009.html) for when both "dx" and "transform" attributes are set on `<text>` elements.

Hopefully this will reduce a few support requests. :)

title: IE9 and CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)
body: In an example that I was trying to use, I need to go across domains. CORS works well in all browsers except <= IE9. Since most of the examples will work in IE9, I figured I'd add the XDR code to make it work. It did not add much extra to the code. The reason for the url.indexOf was that if there is no CORS, the XDR will not work.

title: d3.format: support align and non-decimal formats.
body: This also fixes a minor discrepancy with Python's implementation: format("013,d")(-42000000) now returns "-0,042,000,000" instead of "-042,000,000".

title: Add d3.geo.path.bounds.
body: This computes the bounding box for a given GeoJSON object using the current projection.

title: Fix for WebKit bad CTM when zoom != 1
body:
Fixes these:
#668

https://groups.google.com/d/topic/d3-js/tqJ_V7cV7Eg/discussion

A good place to test to see the diff is the mouse example.
Also I ran make so it changed d3.v2.js and the min... not sure what the pull request equate is for those files.
All the 'real' changes are in core/mouse.js

I refactored your code a little bit so that there is a d3_mouse_getScreenCTM function that just returns the 'fixed' CTM.

I added some extra code to set the html and body position to 'static' before doing the bug test. This is so that the test is more robust - an insane person might have body or html not be at (0,0) and have position not static.

Example:

``` javascript
d3.select('body')
  .style('position', 'absolute')
  .style('left', 0)
  .style('top', '10px');

window.scrollTo(0, 10);
```

Add this to your code and it would trick the regular d3.mouse function to think that bug44083 exists when it might not.

title: Add support for parsing weekdays and week numbers.
body: Also includes support for parsing "%" literals.

title: Update to UglifyJS v1.3.3.
body:
Save 108 gzipped bytes!

Also, update node-canvas to 0.13.0 for better compatibility with Node.js 0.8.x.

title: Automate d3.time.format and d3.format locale generation.
body:
This avoids having to include a large number of locales in the D3 repository itself, and also reduces the potential for typos when transcribing locale mappings. Even if we do want to include many locales, we can include this as a script for easily generating them.

Ideally the generated locale file should be deleted, otherwise unnecessary locale files could be left lying around. A change in the LOCALE environment variable is not currently detected by the Makefile, so I wonder if the current locale should be stored in some kind of dot-file so a change can be detected. Is there a standard way for doing this?

title: Add en_GB locale for d3.time.format.
body: The only difference between this and en_US is `d3_time_formatDate = "%d/%m/%y"`.

title: Add d3.interpolateStringMissing.
body:
Instead of immediately replacing missing start numbers with the corresponding end numbers, d3.interpolateStringMissing interpolates from an arbitrary starting number to each end number.

This is especially useful for working around some browsers that automatically remove optional zeroes from the SVG transform attribute. Rather than using d3.tween with d3.interpolateString, d3.interpolateStringMissing(0) should be more robust.

See #746.

title: Add cubic polynomial splines
body:
Currently hermite splines are being used in a lot of places when you want to generate graphs of functions. Unfortunately these create bezier curves which may reverse eg
http://bl.ocks.org/3315490 and http://bl.ocks.org/3316746

This can be solved by choosing control points that create regular polynomial splines
see http://bl.ocks.org/3316815 and http://bl.ocks.org/3316859

Tests are broken here because the generated paths have changed

title: Issue with DOM Leaks and with visulizations using the packtree layout parents having only one child are obscured.
body: If you use the http://mbostock.github.com/d3/ex/pack.html chart (or any other visualization based the packtree layout); and your parent circle only has one child; the parent is obscured by the child as the calculation makes the parent.size = child.size.    Not sure if this is the best solution; but added code to make parent.size = child.size \* 1.5; in the event the parent only has one child.   Which causes the parent to be visible if it only has one child.

title: Updates to XHR API
body: See my comments in #369

New features:
- selection.attr and similar methods now accept [multi-valued maps](http://bl.ocks.org/3305515)
- added [d3.lab, d3.hcl](http://bl.ocks.org/3014589) and d3.interpolateLab, d3.interpolateHcl
- added [d3.tween](http://bl.ocks.org/3305854)
- added [d3.tsv](http://bl.ocks.org/3305937)
- added [localization for d3.time.format](http://bl.ocks.org/3306234) (including fr_FR and ru_RU)
- added [d3.scale.threshold](http://bl.ocks.org/3306362)
- added [outer padding](http://bl.ocks.org/3310560) for d3.scale.ordinal rangeBands
- added [d3.layout.pack padding](http://bl.ocks.org/3007180)
- added [custom interpolators](http://bl.ocks.org/3310323) for d3.svg.line and d3.svg.area
- added [d3.random.logNormal](http://bl.ocks.org/3048166) and [d3.random.irwinHall](http://bl.ocks.org/3048450)
- improved [d3.time.scale nice](http://bl.ocks.org/3306147)
- fixed [monotone interpolation](http://bl.ocks.org/3310233)
- simplified [transform interpolation](http://bl.ocks.org/3173784)

title: Allow static localization of d3.time.format.
body:
You can now build a locale-specific version of d3.time.format. For example,

``` bash
LOCALE=fr_FR make
```

will pull strings from the time/format-fr_FR.js file, rather than en_US.

title: Custom interpolators for transition.{attr, style}.
body: Fixes #747.

title: Added capability to wrap d3 as an AMD module.
body:
To generate a wrapped d3, do:

```
$ make MODULE_TYPE=amd
```

The wrapped d3 will be found in d3-amd.v2.js and d3-amd.v2.min.js.

title: selection.enter.insertInOrder
body: This spawned from the discussion on #732.  Rather than take a functional argument to `insert`'s `before` argument, a more specialized function seems to make more sense here.

title: Fix rotate transforms with non-zero origin.
body:
Previously, only the angle was being interpolated. Unfortunately, it looks like the origin information is lost when converted to a matrix, so I don't think there's any way to interpolate the angle and origin directly unless of course we parse the string ourselves. :) For example, "rotate(0 100 100)" becomes the identity matrix [1 0 0 1 0 0].

Interpolating the matrix decomposition seems better than dropping the origin altogether.

Edit: clarified why loss of origin information is problematic.

title: Fix nice implementation for time scales.
body: The previous implementation didn't handle polylinear domains correctly.

title: d3.timer: use high resolution timer if available.
body:
This allows us to measure time with sub-millisecond precision, which can make transitions more precise. Currently only supported in Chrome.

See also:
- http://updates.html5rocks.com/2012/05/requestAnimationFrame-API-now-with-sub-millisecond-precision
- http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/webperf/raw-file/tip/specs/HighResolutionTime/Overview.html

title: Add support for interpolating null transform lists.
body: For consistency with [CSS3](http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-transforms/#animation), a null "from" or "to" transform list is replaced by an identity function list whose types match those of the non-null transform list.

title: Fix typo in comments: coallesce → coalesce.
Complex arguments for selection.insert/append
body:
Similar to #732, but with support for node & function arguments for both `selection.insert` _and_ `selection.append`.

My primary use case here is to easily insert nodes in some order (without having to sort the nodes after the fact)

I'm not sure if `core/selection-generation.js` is the right spot for that utility function, but couldn't find any good examples; is there a better spot for it?

title: Selection append support for naked nodes and functions
body:
Hello Mike, 

I'd like to collaborate selection-append support for naked dom nodes and for functions which, according to normal d3 style, will take the `(d, i)` data and index arguments and can return either a node or a qualified or unqualified name for a node.

title: Monotone_cubic_interpolation is implemented slightly incorrectly
body:
because the initial slopes were being set to the sum of the slopes of the secants instead of their average you can end up with wobbly line effects like:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/yzrdvux8kmvehzy/original-1.jpg
So with the slope corrected (the 1st commit) you get
https://www.dropbox.com/s/4h3ba09a3c8gxda/corrected.jpg

(note in the data there are only points at [2001,2002,2003,2004,2005,2006])

This implements the Fitsch-Carlson method which has a slight issue where it doesn't respect local minima in the data.
Note how in https://www.dropbox.com/s/4h3ba09a3c8gxda/corrected.jpg the curve falls below 2.0 just before x=2004. in the data the minimum point is at 2004 however the spline does not reflect that.

To resolve this you can set the initial slope to be 0 at local minima and maxima (the second commit)
see: https://www.dropbox.com/s/pep50cy9jsceyck/improved.jpg for the result.

title: Fixes custom timezone tests for Node.js 0.8.x.
body:
The process.env.TZ trick no longer seems to work. The fix automatically adds an offset to the minutes being set, relative to the current timezone. It assumes that the dates being tested in the scope are not in DST, since the offset is relative to the timezone offset at the epoch.

Fixes #718.

title: Minor optimisation for d3.layout.pack.
body: Uses the identity sin^2(x) + cos^2(x) = 1.

title: Add transition.filter. Fixes #726.
body: Behaves the same as selection.filter.

title: Interpolate "same type" transforms in isolation.
body:
For consistency with CSS3's 2D transforms, two transforms with the same number of transform functions and corresponding functions of the same type are treated differently: each transform function is interpolated in isolation.

This allows us to interpolate many transforms that contain constant functions in a more useful way, e.g.

```
"rotate(<variable>)translate(<constant>)"
```

The variable rotation angle would now be linearly interpolated on its own, keeping the constant translation vector constant.

title: New option for args to selection.append
body:
allows `selection.append(function)`. The function is expected to return
a node for each member of the selection.

title: Minor optimisation and Chrome bug workaround.
body:
There appears to be a [bug in Chrome](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=138552) causing the whole tab to crash when setting the following for a newly-created element without a non-empty class name.

``` js
svgNode.className.baseVal = "";
```

This fix is a minor optimisation: if the current class is empty then removing a class should be a no-op.  It also conveniently works around the Chrome bug.

title: Pass nested selection group index to event listeners
body: Not sure where in the documentation I discovered this (it's not typically mentioned) but in a nested selection, the "group" index is actually [passed to callbacks as the third argument](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/master/src/core/selection-each.js#L10). This fixes the `selection.on` code so it doesn't drop arguments from `selection.each`.

title: d3.time parsing: convert 2-digit years according to POSIX.
body: This is also the convention used by Python 1.5.2+. Values 69-99 are mapped to 1969-1999, and values 0–68 are mapped to 2000–2068.

title: Fix d3.geo.circle clipping.
body:
This uses a new algorithm, based on Weiler-Atherton. The difference is
that we only need to clip against a single line (the circle), so this
simplifies things somewhat. Rough summary:
1. For each ring in each polygon, intersect with the circle and generate
   an array of segments. This same routine is used on its own for
   LineString and MultiLineString features.
2. Since we're dealing with closed polygons, we check the first and last
   segment to see if they should be merged into one.
3. Create a circular linked list containing the intersection points, in
   clockwise order of their position on the circle. For each start
   point, include a reference to the end point.
4. Finally, traverse the linked list, starting with an entering
   intersection point, inserting the segment and then following the
   reference to the end point. Then, interpolate along the circle edge
   to the next (clockwise) point, which should always be an entering
   point, and repeat until the start point is reached. The resulting
   ring is added as a polygon.
5. Continue with step 3 until all entering points have been visited.

To do: assign holes to their correct polygons, perhaps using winding
numbers. At the moment holes are essentially added as separate polygons,
which works for drawing since they're in anticlockwise order.

Fixes #691.

title: Add Google Spreadsheet support to D3
body:
# Google Spreadsheet

Hi Mr. Bostock,

First I would like to thank you for your beautiful code. It is truly a work of art.
### The Problem

I work for a major Brazilian newspaper (Estadão) and others may have the same problem as me. Large companies do not allow to change the header of the server to do CORS, not without months of meetings. This can be a bit stressful. Sometimes we just want to create a visualization with few data and be able to maintain the data from time to time.
### The suggestion

I agree that in general terms is not a good idea to use JSONP. But in the case of GDocs maybe we could make an exception. This would allow, for example, that the samples included in the package operate without requiring a server. Great advantage for beginners. :)
### About the change

I wrote a first implementation of how this might work. It groups the two main ways that google allows to download data from the tables. Via feeds and SQL query (https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/querylanguage). So the client does not need to download the entire table at once. That first implementation has less than 50 lines, but I will try to reduce more.
### Requirements

The table must be configured as public. The first row of the table must have the column names.
#### Restrictions

Google Spreadsheet does not allow more than 20MB or 400.000 cells. So this strategy does not replace a good database.
## Usage

``` javascript
d3.gdocs ({
    url: "", //url and table key
    sql: "", //table selection [optional]
    as_feed: false //strategy used to download data [optional]
}, function (data) {
    //where magic happens
})
```
### Security

The URL is disassembled, reassembled and parsed with a single callback enabled and it will runs within the D3
### Testing

Using the technique of late-loading. Can we test this technique using the current HTML libraries of D3?

**TO-DO** _Include support for choose specific Sheets on table_

I hope that this addition can be useful

Thank you very much

Tcha-Tcho

title: Don't interpret double-pan as double-tap.
body:
Firstly, the last-touched-time was being set on touchend, even if a pan gesture had occurred. This caused a pan quickly followed by a single tap to be interpreted as a double-tap. In this fix, the time is only set on touchstart.

Secondly, the time is cleared on touchmove, so that a pan gesture cancels double-tap detection.

title: Fix #691: remove incorrect last interpolation step.
body:
For closed polygons, the last point should simply be connected to the first clipped point, rather than be clipped to the clipping circle.

Without this last step, the [Azimuthal grid](http://bl.ocks.org/3021474) still works fine, but you can see the inconsistent clip edge when slowly changing the x-origin in the world countries Azimuthal example, because this step is needed to handle closed polygons.

title: Add X-Requested-With to XMLHttpRequest's header
body:
This will fix the error when (if) server-side framework checks request header
before create respond as Ajax

title: Custom d3.svg.{area,line} interpolators.
body:
You can now specify a function as the interpolate property of a line or area,
allowing you to define custom interpolation behavior.

title: Add support for outer padding on rangeBands.
body:
Sometimes you want additional padding between the outer bands and the range
extent. Now you can.

title: Use shortest path for hue in d3.interpolateHsl.
body: Fixes #688.

title: Add d3.tsv for tab-separated values.
body:
This makes the previous d3.csv code a bit more generic via a d3_dsv (delimiter-
separated values) module generator. Fixes #501. (Thanks, @vlandham!)

title: Faster d3.geo.path implementation.
body:
Rather than creating separate arrays for each geometry, a shared buffer is used
and the array is only converted to a string once.

title: Add padding to d3.layout.pack.
body:
The previous method of subtracting slightly from the radius introduces
distortion where smaller circles are disproportionately reduced. For example,
subtracting 1px from the radius scales a circle of radius 5px by 0.64x, while a
circle of radius 50px is only reduced by 0.96x.

By incorporating padding into the layout algorithm, the leaf circles’ area is
still proportional to the associated value. Due to the scale-independent nature
of the layout, the specified padding value is only approximate.

title: Don't transition label positioning attributes.
body:
The axis component no longer uses a transition for the text elements' dy and
text-anchor attributes. This makes it easier to style the labels using post-
selection, since the transition will not override custom attribute values.

title: Fix bug with unexpected transition inheritance.
body:
Prior to this change, transitions used transition.each internally, which had the
unexpected side-effect of enabling transitions on d3.transition(selection) when
called from within a tween function. This would only occur on the first
invocation of the tween function when the elapsed time between the transition
creation and the transition start was greater than the transition delay;
however, this is fairly common as the default delay for transitions is zero.

This bug caused unexpected behavior if you tried to redraw an axis within a
custom tween function: in some cases, the synchronous redraw of the axis would
compete with a concurrent transition, causing unexpected behavior. By avoiding
the use of transition.each internally, the user now controls when automatic
transitions are enabled.

title: initial implementation of chernoff faces
body:
Chernoff faces as announced a while ago on the mailing list. Examples at http://bl.ocks.org/2011590 and http://www.larsko.org/v/hpi/

I've put it under d3.svg for now as that seemed to be the least inappropriate -- certainly happy to move it somewhere else. Rudimentary documentation at the top of the file.

title: Fix for Issue #675
body: Remove spurious whitespace from class name list before splitting to eliminate null strings, which generate an error from classed(value, false).

title: Force alpha tweaks
body: Allow tweaking alpha decay rate and threshold.

title: d3.time.format.iso.parse returns null for invalid date
body: See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1353684/detecting-an-invalid-date-date-instance-in-javascript

title: Don't use document.createElementNS() unless there's a namespace URI
body: I know that pre-SVG browser support isn't high on your priority list, but having to shim `document.createElementNS()` seems like overkill for getting plain ol' HTML DOM manipulation working in browsers that will never support a namespace other than HTML. So here's a commit that only uses `createElementNS()` if there's a namespace URI, otherwise `createElement()`.

title: Always display powers-of-ten tick labels.
body:
Previously, the log scale's tick format would hide all labels when there was not
enough room to display the requested number of ticks; now it at least displays
the power-of-ten labels. Fixes #655.

title: API inconsistency when using Sizzle causing defect in IE9
body: When using Sizzle, the API for `d3_select` changes when there is no element to select. When using Sizzle, `undefined` is returned since `[][0] === undefined`. Without Sizzle, `d3_select` returns `null`. This is a problem, because IE9 does not support calling `HTMLElement.insertBefore` (see selection-insert.js) with `undefined` as the second argument; `null` is fine, though.

title: Fix race condition in transition tests.
body: The transition-test-text callback was failing to fire when using the latest Node.js master (joyent/node@82bcdbb8aaa4cf58917dc8d3fd4fcfc272512a2c).  This was most likely due to these tests being run in a different order due to a different object enumeration order.

title: passing object into .attr()
body:
normally, the .attr() function forces coders to have quite long strings of .attr(key,value) snippets. It would look like: 
  d3.select('#svg').append('circle').attr('r',50).attr('fill','#fff').attr('stroke','#f00');
Changing the function a little bit, it can operate more like the jQuery .css() function. Coders can pass an object of `key : value` pairs that will be looped through and called as a single .attr() command. the new code looks like 
  d3.select('#svg').append('circle').attr({
    "r" : 20,
    "fill" : "red",
    "stroke" : "#fff",
  });

title: add start and end parent != undefined in d3_layout_bundlePath while
body:
An undefined import causes a fatal error in the bundle-radial demo.  This commit avoids the error, the ui will go on to draw a line to a blank node.  To recreate initial undefined error add a un-"name"ed node to one of the imports in examples/data/flare-imports.

Thanks for sharing such an awesome tool.

title: Fix dangling globals in d3.layout.{hierarchy,pie}.
body: Also add missing semicolon to mercator example.

title: "Bundle" interpolation for single-element arrays.
body:
Probably a better fix than #640.

In future we may want to generate some kind of loop, but it's not clear what orientation such a loop should have, so perhaps a "non-line" like this is better as a default.

title: Add support for self-loops to d3.layout.bundle.
body: Self-loops were being bundled as a single-element array, causing issues when used with d3.svg.line.  They are now bundled as a two-element array.  Although this results in a "non-line" when used with "bundle" interpolation, other interpolators could potentially generate a loop using the two-element array.

title: Add nest.mapValues as an alias for rollup.
making force.start() just a wee bit more readable.
body:
No functional change, but making the force.js code that wee bit more readable for a human; it's nice to rely on the intricate combination of parent scopes and function call order there, and it permits one to reduce the number of function parameters if that's a goal, but it makes for a tougher 'read' of what is happening here exactly, at least for me.

(re-issue of pull request which was done based on merged code just a few minutes ago; github didn't see the branch as something different from my 'master' branch thanks to merge instead of rebase/cherrypick)

title: force.js sourcecode readability improvement
body: No functional change, but making the force.js code that wee bit more readable for a human; it's nice to rely on the intricate combination of parent scopes and function call order there, and it permits one to reduce the number of function parameters if that's a goal, but it makes for a tougher 'read' of what is happening here exactly, at least for me.

title: Fix size comparison for circle packing layout.
Fix d3.xhr for local URIs.
body:
It turns out there's a simple way to support almost all local `file://` requests (where req.status is always 0 in current browsers). The only case where this doesn't work is when the file does actually exist but is empty.

I've tested the CORS use case in Chrome and Safari, and local xhr now works in Safari (it won't work in Chrome at the moment unless you relax the strict security settings).

title: Chordratio & new chord SVG
body: I've added the chordratio layout which takes a rectangular array of relationships between entities. Each row represents an entity, each column is that entity's contribution to some total value for the column. I also changed the svg chord to a cubic spline in an attempt to reduce path self-intersections.

title: Add browserify compatibility
body:
Hi,

These 3 little lines make d3 compatible with [browserify](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify) and thus allow developers like me to easily include d3 – or any browserify-compatible module requiring d3 (like cubism.. :D) – in their browserify bundles. Great !

Please merge if OK !

title: Bootstrap d3 build without need for pre-compiled d3.v2.js and package.json
body:
Noticing d3 used Make to build and before seeing the wiki-page @ https://github.com/mbostock/d3/wiki, I stumbled through building it using Make and figuring out npm (forgive me, I've not tried nodejs yet!).  

 $ make clean
 $ make

That didn't work (and I figured out why)...   Ultimately, I think I uncovered a couple subtle things that made bootstraping the build harder than it needed to be IMHO.

These are minor issues...but I think nice-to-have.

As a mater of taste, I don't like the idea of having build artifacts in version control...so before trying to build d3 I removed them (with `make clean`) which prompted the suggestions below:
### made `make package.json` depends on `src/core/core.js`, not pre-compiled `d3.v2.js`

Currently `npm install` depends on -> `node src/package.js` depends on -> `index.js` which depends on -> `d3.vs.js`.  `index.js` requires the dependencies `vows` and `jsdom`.  So, to install the d3 dependencies I need to run `src/package.js` which depends on the same dependencies...  A dead end...

So, I changed `src/package.js` to require the file with version number (the only thing it needs) instead of full `d3.vs.js` which also removes the `jsdom` and `sizzle` deps in `src/package.js`.
### renamed `make install` to `make prepare`

Given it's behavior (AFAICT, it is a helper to install the nodejs dependencies needed for d3 from a compiled package.json specifying the dependencies), it made more sense to name it something else.  In make conventions, `make install` is to install the compiled software onto the system, in this case, we are simply preparing the system for a build.
### `make prepare` depends on package.json

I explicitly specified this dependency in the Makefile.  It seems this make target is perhaps neglected (I don't see it's predecessor `make install` anywhere in the WIKI)... but given that I know nothing about `npm`, using make for all steps of bootstrapping a build environment has appeal to me.
## Install From Source

Ultimately, after these changes, on a clean machine with only make and node, and no pre-existing build artifacts, the build becomes:

``` bash
$ # Prereqs: gnu make and nodejs
make prepare
make 
make test
```

compared to before:

``` bash
npm install
make
make test
```

Slightly cleaner and now works in more cases.
#### Disclaimer

This was way more explanation than necessary, but I am trying to get the hang of markdown, github, and pull-requests, forgive me.

All the best!

cheers,
eric

title: Fix another rounding bug with SI-format.
Fix d3.svg.brush for IE9.
body:
The problem with the old fix was the use of g.select(".background") instead of g.selectAll(".background").  This caused the background rect to get the parent's datum, overriding the initial datum of 0.  The brush mouse handler checks the datum of the event target: a truthy datum means a resize action.

We didn't see this problem in the brush examples because the brush parent elements didn't use data binding.

I've also reverted to using pointer-events: none|null for the fix as this seems more appropriate than display: none|null.

title: Added ability to specify chords with explicit relationships instead of a matrix.
body:
Hi,

I wanted the ability to specify chord data with a simple

{
   source: 0,
   target: 2,
   value: 45,372
}

kind of relationship object.  This also allows explicit declaration of which is the source and which is the target.  (When using a matrix, whichever number is first, or larger, wins.)

I added two new methods to d3.layout.chord:

.relationships(x) 
- gets or sets the relationships array.

.addRelationship(sourceIndex, targetIndex, value)
- pushes an individual relationship onto the relationships array.

I then added code to that closure's relayout() function to use the relationships array to populate the chords and groups arrays.

I've got a sample reworking of the hair-color example chord with the correct dominant hair color highlighted.  I'm having git issues though, and am unable to push the new files.  Happy to send them offline on request.

Feedback is of course appreciated.

Cheers,
Dave

title: Add flag to zoom behavior to control zooming origin.
Update jsdom to v0.2.14.
body: We can finally re-enable those tests!

title: Minor simplification to number regex.
body: If `\d+\.?\d*` doesn't match, then there are no digits before the `.` so no need to match `\d*` in the alternative pattern.

title: Pull request for #565
body: Work in progress for #565

title: Line defined usage example
body: I've added an example for the usage of the `.defined` function, based on the `line` example. For the `data` input, I interspersed `null` values for `y`. When drawing `<circle>`s though, these `null`s don't come out very well, so I `filter`ed the data that comes in for the circle markers.

title: Remove a couple of stray globals.
Fix a bug when interpolating exponent notation.
body: We weren't properly detecting "1.e2" as a valid number.

title: Fix #434: chord groups returned in wrong order.
histogram: deal with the degenerate domain without throwing an exception.
d3.xhr: treat req.status === 0 as error.
body: This occurs during a failed cross-origin request, for example.

title: Ordinal scale inversion
body:
For use with d3.svg.brush e.g. for brushing histograms with ordinal scales.  This is a very simple implementation; ideally we want to take into account the current type of range in use.

If I'm headed in the right direction, I'd be happy to improve it and add tests. :)

title: In d3.behavior.drag, the initial mousedown event should be cancelled
body:
If you don't call preventDefault() on the mousedown event, the browser will select text on the page while you drag. For example, try dragging the circle over the text in this fiddle:
http://jsfiddle.net/M8uga/

This event was being cancelled in the previous version of d3.behavior.drag (before the rewrite), so I'm guessing it was just an oversight.

title: Sorting NaNs with d3.{ascending,descending}.
body:
Previously, this was happening:

``` javascript
[1, 5, NaN, 3, 2].sort(d3.ascending);
[1, 5, NaN, 2, 3]
```

Native sort ignores undefined values, so sorting [1, 5, undefined, 2, 3] worked as expected, but this change fixes d3.ascending and d3.descending for any orderable value, including undefined.

title: Fix background rect brush events for IE9.
body: I'm not sure pointer-events: all is necessary on the parent `<g>`, so I've removed it assuming it's sufficient on the background `<rect>`.

title: Add X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest header to xhr
body:
I'd like to add an `X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest` header to `d3.xhr`. I'm working with the Flask web application framework, so I figured this should be handy. From the Flask docs:

> [**is_xhr**](http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/api/#flask.Request.is_xhr)
> _True_ if the request was triggered via a JavaScript XMLHttpRequest. This only works with libraries that support the `X-Requested-With` header and set it to _XMLHttpRequest_. Libraries that do that are prototype, jQuery and Mochikit and probably some more.

title: Added sizzle to dependencies and index.js
body:
I was trying to use d3 as a node module and was running into problems with d3.select throwing a TypeError:

> require('d3').select('body');
> TypeError: Object [ null ] has no method 'querySelector'

Adding sizzle to the selectors and adding it as a global in index.js resolved the problem.

title:
added missing "

" tags to examples/albers/albers.html
body:
examples/albers/albers.html had some missing "p" tags;
this caused the sliders to display poorly.

title: fix typo on path
body: There's a missing "../../" on the `<script>` tag. This patch makes it consistent with the other examples (and makes the example work with a webserver running on d3/)

title: Use a subpath for closed area interpolation.
body:
This is more relevant for radial areas e.g. when using both stroke and fill simultaneously on the same paths in a stacked radial area.

Related: I've always wondered if it's worth adding line-closed even though it's trivial (just append "Z").  Perhaps this would be a reason to add this i.e. to force use of a subpath for radial areas when line-closed is in use?  Alternatively, we could have a dedicated open/closed/none option that appends "Z" for step-*, too, rather than having separate interpolators for each subtype.  I guess it doesn't really make sense for monotone though.

title: added stream chart example
body: The stream chart example has the same functionality as the current stream example. It uses a stream chart wrapper http://bl.ocks.org/1935509 that supports transitions on data updates.

title: additional colour space for d3
body:
Here is a patch for adding CIE Lab colourspace to d3.

There is a gist up http://bl.ocks.org/1958838 showing the improved perceptual colours for brighter and darker, will add some more for the hues.

title: Fixes #576: leap year bug in d3.time.format.
body: We need to set the date fields from year down, rather than in arbitrary order.

title: d3.layout.hierarchy: Allow internal nodes to have value
body:
This adds the ability for the internal nodes to contribute to their value, instead of their value being entirely composed of their children's values.

Adds a new method to d3.layout.hierarchy() to set `internal_value` in a similar fashion that you set the `value` for leaf nodes. When recursing, check to see if there's a function for internal_value, if there is, call it.

I am new to d3, so I apologize if this is already do-able, or if I left anything out.

title: Inheritance for transition.each.
body:
If you use d3.transition(selection) within the context of a transition.each, the
created transition will automatically inherit the delay, duration and easing of
the parent transition. Likewise, if you use d3.transition(selection) within the
context of a selection.each, it simply returns the passed-in selection with no
transition at all. This makes it easier to create components, such as the axis,
that support automatic transitions.

title: Add selection.multiply.
body:
This is similar to selection.each, except you get a single-element selection and
a transition function. This makes it easy to implement components that support
automatic transitions when called on selections, such as the axis and brush.

title: update to latest jsdom
body:
The update is to get the most recent version of contextify
which is a dependency of jsdom. Previous versions of 
contextify always generate a 64 library module. v0.6.11 of
node on macos is a 32-bit ARCH. The latest version of 
contextify  builds an ARCH that matches node NOT the arch
of the system.

See: https://github.com/brianmcd/contextify/issues/19

title: JS doesn't like "%" as the first char in a property name, this probably ...
body: ...needs to be expanded to catch other invalid characters.

title: Improve readability
body: Improvements to readability at the cost of a few bytes

title: Add note about running the tests
Don't block click events entirely on touch devices.
body: This preventDefault call prevents the click event from firing at all.

title: Expose d3_selection_enterPrototype for better extensibility
Generalize gravity to a field in force layout
body:
This can be a flexible tool for certain effects. In my case, it is
having a single element in the centre (achieved with `e.fixed = 1`),
whilst everybody else tries to be a bit far away, but not too far away.
So, I have a moat field where there is centrifugal force if you are more
than R away from centre, and centripetal force if you are less than R.

As a special case (and the default), this is the traditional gravity
field.

Implementation is simple too.

title: Fix bugs relating to inheritance of built-in object prototype properties.
body:
You'll love this one!

I've been over-cautious here, so you may not care about all of these cases.  The main one is data joins; I think that's a real issue, especially on Firefox where the `"watch" in {} === true`.

The only case I didn't think worth bothering with was d3_geo_type.

title: Support HSV colors
body: This branch adds support for HSV colors. I implemented most of the API of HSL. What's not implemented (If it's desired), can easily be implemented by converting the HSV to HSL, doing the computation, and converting back.

title: V2.8.0
body: Staging branch for v2.8.0.

title: Initial touch support for d3.svg.brush.
body:
This is just the single-touch version. Multitouch might be nice as a way to simulate the alt+drag behaviour available in the mouse version.

Fixes #418.

title: Prevent next tick when force.stop is called.
body: This is useful when stopping the layout in response to a user action, e.g. if another layout is used to position the nodes in an event handler.  In this case, we don't want the next tick of the force layout to run as it could undo the positioning work done in the event handler.

title: Add PivotGraph (rollup) layout example.
body: This is ported from the Protovis implementation, [pv.Layout.Rollup](http://mbostock.github.com/protovis/jsdoc/symbols/pv.Layout.Rollup.html). The only difference is that the rollup nodes are not instances of any original nodes (Protovis used pv.extend).  Users are expected to use the "x" and "y" properties of the rollup node, or alternatively the "rolled up" nodes can be retrieved via the "nodes" property.

title: Add "resume" and "stop" events to the force-directed layout
body:
The motivation for this patch is to allow for a layout to hide the "whizzing and zooming" part of the process and only render the network once it is stable.

Note that "start" isn't implemented since it is functionally identical to "resume".

title: Decorative brush resizers + touch support.
body:
The brush component now allows you to add decorative elements to serve as brush
resizers, while keeping the default behavior of a few invisible pixels on the
edge of the extent. Any element you add to ".resize" containers can serve as
visible handles for the brush.

This commit also fixes two small bugs with the brush component. First, we now
track the offset between the extent edge and the mouse, rather than immediately
jumping the extent edge to the mouse position; this was barely noticeable
previously due to the resizers being so thin, but it is very noticeable with
large resizers. Second, the default behavior for the SPACE key is not prevented
whilst dragging.

title: Add constrained centre zoom example.
body: Better version of #504.

title: Add zoom translate extent example (mercator).
body: Just to show it can be done. :)

title: Continuous integration tracking with Travis
body:
It would be neat to have the automated tests run on d3, and tracking over time of how they fare. Travis provides this for free, and I just went through the easy http://about.travis-ci.org/docs/user/getting-started/ guide to try setting it up for my d3 fork. My output from the two last test commits is here (and this view is also the main feature I personally seek): http://travis-ci.org/#!/johan/d3/builds …which also showed up like this in the Freenode IRC channel #d3-travis I noted for live notifications of the build bots:

09:09 travis-ci: [travis-ci] Change view : https://github.com/johan/d3/compare/d86074b...1db25aa

...and like this, in the build hook emails I tested (all notification setup is in .travis.yml): http://mailinator.com/maildir.jsp?email=d3-travis It might of course be worth turning off testing on node.js 0.7 (I tried it to see how it fared) and perhaps tweak other Travis config flags as per http://about.travis-ci.org/docs/user/build-configuration/ at your discretion. :-)

title: Define behavior for mismatched domain & range.
Minor tweaks.
body: Unimportant tweaks: typos in comments, simplifications to examples, removal of extraneous semicolon.

title: Add index.js for easier usage within Node.
body:
This allows you to require("d3") with no additional dependencies, and without
polluting the global namespace. Fixes #475.

title: Add new '%s' format to d3.time.format for the ordinal date suffix.
body:
This change adds a new `%s` format to d3.time.format which prints the English ordinal suffix of the formatted date.

For example, `d3.time.format("%b %e%s")` used to format 01 Jan 1990 would output `Jan  1st`.

title: IEEE 754 range() error
body:
`range()` was causing an error because of IEEE 754 arithmetic. For example:

``` javascript
d3.range(0.2, 0.4, 0.1) === [0.2, 0.30000000000000004]
```

So I've implemented a simple fix by converting any floats to integers, then converting back after the arithmetic is complete. Also included is an additional test case to test for this condition.

title: Make the "auto-scaling" time formats use 24-hour hours
body: I'm not sure if it's worth making this an option; but if it's not then 24-hours really are more universally useful than 12-hours + am/pm.  :-)

title: Rewrite of d3.behavior.zoom.
body:
The extent functionality is simplified, such that the zoom behavior only
supports an extent on the scale factor. Furthermore, the extent is expressed as
a scale factor rather than a zoom level, for consistency. An extent on translate
is no longer supported; this isn't possible unless the zoom behavior also knows
the size of the canvas.

The scale transform functionality is also simplified; simply register an x or y
scale, and the zoom behavior will automatically update the domain before a zoom
event is dispatched. If you change the scale's domain programmatically, you can
simply reassign the scale to the zoom behavior.

Both of these changes are strictly backwards-incompatible. However, since this
class is undocumented, I'll probably let this slide with a minor version bump
rather than waiting until v3.

This commit also reduces the scroll speed slightly, since the previous
implementation seemed a little too fast for my liking. It would be easy to make
the scroll speed configurable as a future enhancement.

Implementation note: rather than using global event listeners on the window, and
needing to copy local state into globals on interaction start, the zoom behavior
now uses closures that are temporarily bound (e.g., mousemove and mouseup are
bound on mousedown, and removed on mouseup).

Fixes #484, allowing scale and translate to be get or set externally.
Fixes #485, providing an example of integration with d3.geo.projection.
Fixes #487, using a scale extent rather than a zoom-level extent.

title: Fix polygon.centroid for open polygons.
body:
The implementation assumed closed polygons, but it should work on either. This
is a partial fix for #443.

title: Minimize d3.interpolateTransform.
body: Fixes #480.

title: Allow event firing to be chained.
Don't use getComputedStyle to fetch current styles.
body:
This was causing issues with getting/setting font-size as it was not always consistent with the value set via .style("font-size", …), which uses .style.setProperty internally:
1. It turns out getComputedStyle returns different font sizes at different full-page zoom levels in WebKit (but not in Firefox).
2. Moreover, computed style sizes are always converted to pixels, so this may cause issues when interpolating any non-pixel sizes.

Maybe there is a good reason why computed styles are being used?  I only noticed this due to using full-page zoom in Chrome and occasionally seeing a font-size style not being set properly.  This is because of the short-circuit in transition().style(…), that checks if you're setting it to the same value that's already there.  In my case, the value reported to be there was not equivalent to the value I was trying to set.

I'm not sure if this is specific to fonts, but I checked setting the width style and that wasn't affected by zooming (aside from the coercion to pixel value).

title: add option to arrange axis labels automatically
body:
Introduces the "arrange" option for the axis components. If set to true and the
axis labels overlap, it will use a simple linear probing algorithm to shift the
labels such that they do not overlap anymore. Adds an element line.tickPointer
that will point from the axis tick to the shifted label. Also adds the class
tick to the axis tick line to be able to distinguish the two.

This is a preliminary implementation that doesn't allow a lot of customisation
and provides only the most basic functionality. The new option defaults to
false, in which case there is no change to the previous behaviour.

Example at http://bl.ocks.org/1678215

Not particularly useful in this context, more so in conjunction with https://github.com/mbostock/d3/pull/326

title: Fix treemap overhang problem.
body:
This also fixes #136 so I've removed the now redundant check for non-zero v if the flush flag is set.

The overhanging rectangles seem more likely to occur when rounding is turned on, because positions sometimes get rounded up and overflow the allowed range that is currently being filled.

title: Always give width/height attribute to background rect from brush component
body: When using the brush component for just the x-axis or just the y-axis, a width or height attribute will be not be given on the background rect and this was causing parse errors in the SVG rasterizer I'm using. The fix just adds a default height/width of 0 for all cases, one or both of which will get overwritten later on.

title: Basic array bisect accessor implementation
body:
Here's a basic implementation of accessors for array bisect methods for #451. Couple potential issues though:
- Should the accessor also be applied to the `x` (search) value? For my current use case or two, the answer is a pretty decided "no" (I'm typically looking for an object near a raw time or similar value) but perhaps this is not consistent with other accessor-taking methods?
- Would it be useful to change the argument order, or at least look for null in the initial lo/hi arguments? At least with something like `bisect` it should be fairly a safe assumption the caller has the array referenced by a variable, but it still seems unfortunate that using an accessor would require explicitly providing the (heretofore optional) search-limiting arguments: `d3.bisect(a, 0, a.length, acc)`

title: Fixed force layout .drag / .px and .py errors
body:
Previous position values (.px/.py) were being set to an intermediate value in tick() processing, causing jumping and drag errors. Only shows up in high-movement graphs; slightly visible in this example: http://bl.ocks.org/1062383 (mouse over pieces and watch the stutter as the pieces "jump" a bit) 

Since o.x and o.y are updated several times (to intermediate values) throughout tick(), we have to capture
.px and .py at the beginning of the function, rather than just before we apply friction to the updated .x and .y values. As a side-effect, the drag code had to be updated to directly modify .x and .y rather than .px and .py.

title: IE comma parse error
body: I'm compiling this with Closure Compiler and it won't allow trailing commas (I believe IE8 and below don't support trailing commas)

title: A fix for Issue 210 concerning inaccurate results from .round()
body: This patch make .round() more accurate by avoiding the hard to represent 10^-n.

title: initial implementation of variable width line
body:
Simulates variable width lines by drawing and connecting two boundary lines. Can be used in much the same way as d3.svg.line, except that the "fill" attribute does what the "stroke" attribute does for normal lines.

I suppose wrappers could be added to make it behave exactly like d3.svg.line (i.e. intercept .attr calls), but I think explaining how it's done in the documentation would be a better option that would offer people more flexibility.

Example at http://bl.ocks.org/1642835

title: Fix polylinear descending domains or ranges.
body: Fixes #446.

title: Dragrect example and linechart example
body:
Hi,

2 additional examples that are candidates for d3 - 
1. Another example for drag with a rectangle that can be moved or resized using drag handles.
2. A linechart using Tipsy tooltips

I learned a lot trying to get these to work. Thanks for a great charting library!

title: Make the voronoi implementation extensible.
body:
This is a relative small change that makes d3.geom.voronoi more extensible. The current implementation assumes that users are only interested in the cell boundaries. However, for some code I'm working on I also need the neighbors of each cell.

In order to make this possible with as little changes as possible I propose this patch. In stead of calling d3.geom.voronoi only with a set of vertices it now also takes an optional callback parameter. This parameter should be an object that provides two methods:
- handle(e) // Handle edge addition
- result()    // finalize and return results.

In my patch the default behavior of d3.geom.voronoi is unchanged as I moved the original anonymous function into a default edgehandler which is used when the handler parameter is undefined.

This patch allows me to install my own edgehandler which records the required information.

Comments, questions and suggestions for improvements welcome of course.

Cheers,

Bertjan

title: Add d3.behavior.{mouse, touches}: supports both SVG and HTML.
body:
Do we still need an alias for backwards compatibility if this is going into v3.0?

It would be nice to have some examples of HTML-only d3.behavior.{drag, zoom}.

See #386.

title: Optimise selection.order.
body:
A small optimisation: only call insertBefore() if node.nextSibling isn't already what we want, so that document nodes that are already in the correct order can be skipped.

A rudimentary benchmark in Chrome on 1,000 nodes looks promising: roughly 7x faster when ordering an unchanged data array.  Negligible impact on ordering based on a randomised data array due to the extra conditional check: around 1% overhead for the same benchmark (30μs per call).

I got similar results in Firefox.

title: More multi-value map support.
body:
Tests included!
- selection.classed
- selection.on
- transition.attr
- transition.style

See #277.

title: fix for calendar example
body: the calendar example has drawn wrong path for some timezone, the t1 will be previous year instead, since t0 is not UTC timezoned

title: New pluck function to easily obtain an array of values from common properties
bugfix for the calendar display (e.g. http://mbostock.github.com/d3/ex/calendar.html)
body:
This edit fixes the days vs. months outline drawing error as visible at, f.e.:
  http://mbostock.github.com/d3/ex/calendar.html

The magic is to replace 
  .getUTCMonth() + 1
with
  .getUTCMonth() + 2
so that each calculated month' outline renders the outline for one month only - the original code rendered an outline around the whole year, then separate lines between the months within the year, where the latter are double-drawn as both halves of the calculated path overlap.

The other bit of change assigns the 'qX-9' class for day cells which do not have a data value. Merely a cosmetic/superfluous thing.

title: Treat undefined like null when setting html/text.
body:
Fixes #405.

I've updated the tests but I'm waiting for tmpvar/jsdom#373 to be merged before they actually work properly.

title: Fix d3.svg.axis path and d3.scale.ordinal().rangeExtent() for explicit ordinal range.
d3.layout.pie: return arcs in original data order.
body: Fixes #406.

title: Handle single node in d3.layout.cluster.
body:
If there is only one node, it will be positioned at y = 0, which is consistent with d3.layout.tree.

Fixes #396.

title: Update dependencies and use "devDependencies".
body:
Using "devDependencies" prevents "vows" etc. from being installed if D3 is being installed as a dependency. I'm not sure whether "jsdom" counts as a true dependency or not as we only really use it for the tests.

I've also added a "scripts": {"test": …} parameter, which specifies what happens when you run "npm test".

title: Add GeometryCollection support to d3.geo.bounds
body: Simple patch to allow iterating over GeometryCollection type missing from d3.geo.bounds.

title: Remove redundant namespaces from examples and d3.svg.*.
body: Do we also want to update all examples and tutorials for consistency?

title: d3.transform fixes.
body:
This fixes various corner cases involving negative and zero scales, as well as proper support for skewX, which previously wasn't being computed correctly.

Includes browser-based tests!

Admittedly they could be a lot nicer e.g. animated D3-based progress bar and setTimeout to avoid browser lockup, but they did their job. :)

title: Fix d3.transform for scale(1,-1) and scale(-1,1).
body:
Fixes #377.

Can't add tests yet as JSDOM has no SVGMatrix implementation. :(

title: Script to build html index
body:
Mike,

I found it helpful to throw a quick script together to build an index page containing links to all of the examples.

Please pull if you think it might be useful for others.

Best wishes,

Alex

title: Origin support for drag behavior.
body: This obviates the need to maintain an origin externally (such as this.**origin**).

title: Update JSDOM and Vows versions (Node.js v0.6.x compatibility).
body:
This required changing assert.length to assert.lengthOf in tests, due to a Vows.js change to be compatible with Node.js v0.6.x.  [Further details](https://github.com/cloudhead/vows/pull/141).

Hence this also makes the D3.js test suite fully compatible with Node.js v0.6.x.

title: Dispatch "dragstart" on mousemove.
body:
Previously this was being dispatched on mousedown, which doesn't necessary indicate a drag gesture has started (it might be a stationary click).

Also, call event.preventDefault() on mousedown (to prevent default behaviours like text selection).

This is backwards-incompatible if you relied on d3.event.{dx,dy} being zero on dragstart, but I doubt anyone would have relied on that.

title: Make axes reorderable in parallel coords example.
body: Transitioning all these paths is a bit slow, perhaps we should just have the axes titles draggable on their own.

title: Fix minor bug in exponent notation interpolation.
body: It wasn't matching `xe+y` correctly.

title: Use single loop for d3.extent.
body: I was tempted to just make d3.min and d3.max use d3.extent internally, to avoid having to write extra tests. :)

title: Remove stray global in brush example.
Hi! I cleaned up your code for you!
body:
Hi there!

This is WhitespaceBot. I'm an [open-source](https://github.com/Gunio/WhitespaceBot) robot that removes trailing white space in your code, and gives you a gitignore file if you didn't have one!  

Why whitespace? Whitespace is an eyesore for developers who use text editors with dark themes. It's not  a huge deal, but it's a bit annoying if you use Vim in a terminal. Really, I'm just a proof of  concept - GitHub's V3 API allows robots to automatically improve open source projects, and that's really cool. Hopefully, somebody, maybe you!, will fork me and make me even more useful. My owner is [funding a bounty](http://gun.io/open/12/add-security-flaw-fixing-features-to-whitespacebot) to anybody who can add security fixing features to me. 

I've only cleaned your most popular project, and I've added you to a list of users not to contact again, so you won't get any more pull requests from me unless you ask. If I'm misbehaving, please email my owner and tell him to turn me off! If this is pull request is of no use to you, please just ignore it.

Thanks!
WhiteSpacebot from [Gun.io](http://gun.io).

title: Allow event.changedTouches to be used instead of event.touches.
body: This is because the "touchend" event removes the touch from event.touches on iOS, but it can still be accessed via event.changedTouches.

title: Configurable extents for d3.behavior.zoom.
body:
This is my take on the matter. I'm open to suggestions for API improvements!

I believe this also fixes #341 as the domain is no longer stashed in the scale, although I haven't tested modifying the scale domain elsewhere.

See also: #247.

title: Tiny prettification of the calendar examples
body: Non-data dates were previously showed as "NaN%" and "undefined" respectively. This is the local fix approach. Another might be letting d3.format grow some handling for undefined, null or NaN values, say, d3.format(".01%", undefined, "N/A"); for giving a fallback for illegal input.

title: Update UglifyJS, JSDOM and Vows.
body:
I ran the tests on the newly minified files too, for good measure, and everything passed.

You'll need to run `npm update` in the `d3` directory to update `./node_modules/`.

title: Better handling of empty domains for nice scales.
body: This addresses #337.

title: Add tests for d3.geom.polygon and fix centroid bug.
body:
d3.geom.polygon(…).area() assumes screen pixel coordinates with (0, 0) at the top left, and y increasing going downwards.  This results in a positive area for counterclockwise coordinates.  Howver, the default centroid calculation was assuming "usual" Cartesian coordinates with y increasing going upwards, hence the centroid coordinates were incorrectly multiplied by -1.

This fix won't affect d3.geo.path(…).centroid() as it passes a constant to d3.geom.centroid.

This includes a _really_ simple test, I'm sure we can flesh these out as time goes on. :)

Also, I wasn't sure if polygon coordinates should end at the start point or not, so I've tested both for now.

title: Fix tests in Linux.
body:
The directory listing order is different from OS X and so the tests are run in a slightly different order.  Other tests were leaving data bound to the "body" element, and this data was then propagated when new elements were appended, and thus messed up the data propagation test.

You can probably leave out the `html("")` changes as they were a red herring, but I don't think they do any harm.  Maybe we need a reusable "setup" function that clears the body element of any data and elements.

title: Add d3.mean.
body:
Uses Welford's algorithm to avoid overflow.

See #245.

title: Fix transitioning styles to null (removal).
body: This prevents styles being set to the string `"null"`, which causes a fatal error in IE9 due to being an invalid CSS style in most cases.

title: add geotranslate method to projections and tests
body:
Geotranslate works like translate but takes projection coordinates as input. It
is also scale independent, i.e. there is no need to adjust geotranslate after
changing the scale. The primary use of this function is to move the map to a
specific place.

Unfortunately this introduces some repeated code to maintain the translation internally independent of the scale. I didn't find a good way of avoiding this though and would be grateful for any pointers.

title: make Makefile GNU make v3.82 compatible
body:
Quote from NEWS file:

In previous versions of make it was acceptable to list one or more explicit
targets followed by one or more pattern targets in the same rule and it
worked "as expected". However, this was not documented as acceptable and if
you listed any explicit targets AFTER the pattern targets, the entire rule
would be mis-parsed. This release removes this ability completely: make
will generate an error message if you mix explicit and pattern targets in
the same rule.

title: fix bug that causes chord layout to break in Opera
body:
The chord layout uses an assigment like x += y to specify the end angle of a
chord segment. This seems to return the new value in most browsers, but the old
value (i.e. x - y) in Opera.

title: allow to specify custom tick positions
body:
Custom positions for ticks can be specified like
ticks([1, 20, 33, 56])
which will give ticks in those positions.

Hey Mike,

First time I am using Github, so I am not so sure about the way to send a pull request properly. A year ago, Vadim Ogievetsky gave me some of his python files to turn shp files into json ones. I have just slightly modified the code so that we can do the same thing with GeoJSON for d3.

I asked Vadim a while ago if I could share his files and he was ok with it. Feel free to ignore this request, if you think it's irrelevant but I thought it might help some people around.

title: Cylindrical projections.
body: My name is Jason and I'm addicted to map projections.

title: Add support for non-zero latitude origin to Bonne.
body:
Most GIS software don't seem to support this, and the formulas only refer to a longitudinal origin (the "central meridian"), presumably because it's trivial.

We could easily have a georotational projection that performs rotations about all three axes, not just z- and y-.  There is an argument for keeping an origin parameter for some projections though, if the maths is simplified.

We don't have an origin parameter for the Mercator projection; I think I used the albers projection as a starting point for Bonne.  So I wouldn't mind dropping the origin parameter from Bonne altogether if you think that's reasonable.  Otherwise, here is a working latitudinal origin!

title: prototypal inheritance between hierarchical objects causes infinite recursive loops due to prototype chain
Minor cleanup of force-cluster example.
body: We don't need to reselect now that appending nodes to the entering selection are automatically added to the updating selection.

title: Add Bonne geographic projection.
body: Note that the Werner projection is a special case with standard parallel at 90°N, and the Sinusoidal projection is also a special case with standard parallel at 0°N.

title: Npm doesn't necessarily install dependencies under d3/node_modules
body: On my system (homebrew 0.8, node.js 0.4.8, npm 0.3.18), "npm install" installs d3's dependencies below /usr/local/lib/node ($NODE_PATH), not d3/node_modules – this tweak should make "make test" work with either configuration.

title: Less zealous click cancelling.
body:
The click event is prevented from propagating when a drag has occurred i.e. the mouse has moved between mousedown and mouseup.  This is because a click event will be triggered after a mousedown and mouseup have occurred on the same element.  However, we were cancelling the next click event _anywhere_, regardless of whether mousedown and mouseup occurred on the same element or not.

As a sanity check, we also check that the click event was triggered on the same element that mousedown _and_ mouseup occurred on, before cancelling it.  Just in case!

title: Append should accept raw nodes (listed as 'todo?' in selection-append.js)
body:
This commit lets you pass raw nodes to append, and includes relevant tests.

One thing that might be confusing to users is that when you give `.appendChild()` a node that is already on the DOM, that node will be moved rather than copied, so when you pass a node to `.append()` it will in effect only append it to the last element in the selection.
I don't expect it will be a problem though, since only advanced users will be passing raw nodes to `.append()`.

title: Fix a bug when charge forces are zero.
body: This was causing a divide by zero in the center-of-charge calculation.

title: Better log ticks.
body: This adds support for filtering the log ticks, such that fewer ticks can be generated to fit in a small space. This can be used in conjunction with a custom tick format as well. This commit also changes the default log tick format to be exponential rather than precision, for consistency.

title: Add si prefix format
body:
This right here's stolen directly from gnuplot, and is something Cube made me want. (thanks for cube, btw!)

This adds the specifier "s" to format numbers into nearest-SI-prefix format- so "127545" -> "128k", "1500" -> "1.5k", etc. Good for dealing with giant counters, and (for me) more natural to read than exponent notation. Currently, this is a slightly deficient implementation in that it (1) completely ignores precision and (2) falls back on its own degenerate representation when |x| > 10^26, but I wanted to at least check in to see if this'd be wanted before spending more time on it.

title: fix sigfig ('r') formatting with precision using zero as input
body: presently this returns NaN due to an attempt at taking the log of zero. i've special-cased it out to just short-circuit to .toPrecision(p) on zero input.

title: Add d3.behavior.select for brush+filter.
body:
This is typically called on an svg:rect element.  Dragging on the element's parent will fire "selectstart", "select" and "selectend" events with d3.event having x, y, dx and dy set appropriately: dx and dy will be updated as the rectangle is sized.  Dragging on the element will also fire these events, but only x and y will be updated while dragging: this is because the rectangle is being moved.

Fixes #248.

title: Fix sort due to lack of NodeList.prototype.sort.
body:
NodeList doesn't support .sort() directly, so we need to convert to a real Array first.  I've done this in selectAll for efficiency i.e. this avoids a new Array being created every time the same selection is sorted.  However, it may be slightly more efficient to create the Array only when sorting, to avoid unnecessary Array creation when sorting isn't used, which is probably the common case.

Unfortunately it's difficult to test this because JSDOM uses a real Array instead of a NodeList!

title: Update tests for d3.layout.pack.
body: Improves the residual floating point error test, and adds a test for coincident circles.

title: Modified d3.csv to include an optional parameter allowing you to specify
body:
Modified d3.csv to include an optional parameter allowing you to specify type of dilimiter as a string - pipe, tab, etc. 

This mimics the behavior of the R function read.csv().

title: add equirectangular projection
body: Straightforward equirectangular projection as an alternative to Mercator.

title: Adding chargeMultiplier to individual points in d3.layout.force
body: I added some code so that the force layout can give different charges to individual nodes. The way to do this is to simply add node.chargeMultiplier (default amounts to 1).

title: Add a ticks function to chart.bullet
body:
The function takes two arguments:
- d:       The data for the bullet chart
- scale:   The x scale for the chart (refered to as x1 in the main
          function)

The default behaviour is to simply call scale.ticks(8) as per the
previous behaviour.

Here's a coffeescript example of how I'm using it. I only want 0 and
useful points on my chart:

```
 .ticks((d, scale) -> _.uniq d3.merge [[0], d.markers, d.measures, d.ranges])
```

title: Add innerRadius and outerRadius to pie layout
body:
I think it makes sense to be able to specify these for the pie chart layout so that one does not need to apply these to the arc.

After all, someone using the pie layout most likely does not want to manipulate the individual arc lengths.

This change also adds default values so that if an inner radius is not set the arc.centroid function does not return NaNs. As cool as donut charts are, I'm sure there are people who may not specify the inner radius and wonder why they can't have labels (as I ran into while learning).

title: Add d3.geo.greatcircle.
body:
Can be used to generate great circle paths.  Similar to R's geosphere.gcIntermediate (in which I discovered a bug, while writing the test case for this!)

Includes d3.geo.greatcircle().distance for computing the shortest geo path distance using the Haversine formula.

For a tutorial on using great circles, see: http://flowingdata.com/2011/05/11/how-to-map-connections-with-great-circles/

Avoids a spurious layout restart if the mouse hasn't moved.

Fixes #207.

title: Fix division by zero in partition
body: This patch fixes a smal problem with d3.layout.partition. If there is a node whose value is zero and which has some children, each child's `dx` will become NaN because of division by zero.

title: zindex selection method that handles SVG
body:
The quirk of SVG not supporting `z-index` has come up a few times in the group:

```
http://groups.google.com/group/d3-js/browse_thread/thread/9480326bbd980459
http://groups.google.com/group/d3-js/browse_thread/thread/a3f47cbeb1043892
```

And the correct answer seems to be, "use sort to reorder the SVG nodes".
This is a selection method that just does that for SVG, and otherwise calls style().

If you think this is okay, we should probably put a little check in the style() to call this function so people can use either

```
.style("z-index", ...)
```

or

```
.zindex(...)
```

Also please let me know if there are any style guides / pull request etiquette for D3---I looked around but couldn't find anything.

title: Fix handling of zero-sized nodes.
body:
Previously, negative or zero sizes were short-circuiting the worst() function by always returning Infinity, instead of being ignored for the score computation.

I've had to add a check for `s` to prevent `0/0` when computing the score for a single zero node too.

Fixes #233.

title: Time Scale Refinements
body: I've added two functions to the time scale setup: interval and intervalFormat. They allow you to make ticks at particular time intervals (e.g. every month or every hour) and to label those ticks uniformly, instead of defaulting to the highest-order label.

title: Improve IE9 compatibility
body:
This adds simple patches for IE9 support by patching Array.map and 
creating a simple workaround for {elt}.style.setProperty() which IE9
doesn't support.

IE9 does not support {elt}.style.setProperty(name,value,priority)
but this can be worked around using
{elt}.style[name] = value

Tested examples/ with this in place and every example I checked
worked in IE9 (specifically, this fixes bar, bullet, albers, force directed graphs,
which don't work without the patch).

Thanks.

title: Add support for padding to treemap layout.
body:
The new "padding" property is an array of [top, right, bottom, left], or a function that returns such an array for a given node.

I had to change the internal `scale()` function too for this to work as the areas need to be recomputed one level at a time, instead of recursively all at once.  It seems more elegant to take an array of child nodes for this reason as that's when it's used.

I modified the example to use padding for testing, but you might want to revert this.

Lastly, is there any point in supporting a single numerical argument as padding for convenience?

title: Fix retrieval of width/height for horizon chart.
Minor optimisation.

title: eliminate "this.parentNode is null" errors
body: verify that the node to remove after a transition actually has a parent node

title: Prevent RangeError in force layout on Safari.
body:
For very large force layouts, Safari was throwing "RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded".  I think this is due to Safari having a smaller call stack than Chrome and FireFox.  In any case, this fix replaces `forEach` with a while loop, which should be faster in all browsers as well as reducing the call stack size needed and thus fixing the Safari issue.

Note that it ignores `undefined` elements of the `quad.nodes` array.  I assumed it's normal for these to be there, as `quad.nodes.forEach` also ignores these elements and perhaps that's why `forEach` was being used.

Thanks to Vicenzo Menanno for noticing this issue!

Error: Cannot find module '../../UglifyJS'

title: Micro-optimisation: remove arguments check.
body:
This is around 6x faster when using V8's Crankshaft as the JIT bails due to the `arguments.length` reference.  I know the `arguments.length` check is used extensively in D3 and it's nice to keep it this way for consistency, but it might be worth replacing in this case as centroid may well get "hot" e.g. when used intensively for geo visualisations.

Still, micro-optimisations are debatable and this will likely become obsolete as Crankshaft gets smarter, so take with a pinch of salt!

title: Couple of tweaks to reset gravity.

Secondly, if the user switches to another window, the gravity coordinates are nullified (otherwise the appropriate `mouseout` event may be missed).

title: fix minor errors
body:
I'm working with a system that concatenates all the JS into one file, and it doesn't deal well with the minor syntax issues in this file. 

In particular, the lack of ';' means that each anonymous function trys to call the next:

(...d3.js...)()
(...d3.layout.js...)()

putting semicolons at the end makes JS a lot happier.

The other minor change is a trailing-comma fix that would blow up explorer - I know there's know way you'd support old explorerers, but JS compilers/minimizers balk at the trailing comma...

title: Semicolon needed after modules
body:
Modules should end with a semicolon so that they're parsed correctly even if several modules are concatenated into the same file.
Without a semicolon, JavaScript evaluates

```
a = b + c
(d + e).print()
```

as

```
a = b + c(d + e).print();
```

rather than

```
a = b + c;
(d + e).print();
```

title: Add "boid" flocking: d3.ai.boid().
body:
Includes interactive "voroboids" example!

I appreciate this may be a bit too esoteric even for inclusion in its own module.  Still, it might be useful for "arty" uses of D3. :)

I played with the idea of having `d3.ai.boids` process a whole flock of boids at once, but I think `d3.ai.boid` (singular) better represents the fact that the flocking behaviour emerges from rules applied to each individual boid.  Having said that, it might be more reusable to process a whole flock at once, and properties such as "neighbour radius" optionally be set with a function that gets applied to each boid.

Also, just realised I've used the British spellings for "neighbourRadius" and "gravityCentre"; I guess I should change that. :-)

title: Instantiating enter affects update.
body: Previously, if you instantiated the enter selection via append or insert, you'd have to re-select to unify the enter and update selection (the post-transform nodes). Now, simply by appending or inserting the entering nodes, the update selection automatically refreshes, obviating the need for a reselect. If you still want to perform actions only on the updating nodes, you can do so by performing these actions before instantiating the enter selection.

title: Simplify subclassing of hierarchy layout.
body: The subclasses can't use the same object as the parent class, because they are functions. But, there's no reason to duplicate the code that rebinds the methods onto the subclass.

title: Tweens are now optional.
body: If the tween function returns null, then no tween will be applied for the specified element. The default tween function now returns null if the start and end value are the same, thus avoiding redundant interpolation.

title: .debug()
body:
A tiny utility function to take a peek into the chain with console.log(). 

Usage: `.debug('Tag to print with the result')`

Example:

```
vis.selectAll("g.arc")
  .data(arcs(data0, data1))
  .enter()
  .debug("Data: ")
  .append("svg:path")
  .attr("d", arc)
  .debug("End of chain: ");
```

title: .attr( map ) and .attr( function() {return map} )
body:
`attr` can now take a map of name/value pairs, by calling itself recursively for each pair.
`attr` can now take a function which returns a map.

title: Add d3.svg.superformula.
body:
I followed the same pattern as d3.svg.symbol to add a d3.svg.tweenable that can interpolate simple shapes like rectangle, ellipse, circle, diamond, gear, drop. More complex shapes can be generated as they are all derived from the Superformula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superformula).

You can see a working example here: http://christopheviau.com/var/d3_tween/index.html.
